Name: The Shepherd
Line1: How sweet is the Shepherd's sweet lot!
Line2: From the morn to the evening he stays;
Line3: He shall follow his sheep all the day,
Line4: And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
Line5: For he hears the lambs' innocent call,
Line6: And he hears the ewes' tender reply;
Line7: He is watching while they are in peace,
Line8: For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

Name: The Echoing Green
Line1: The sun does arise,
Line2: And make happy the skies;
Line3: The merry bells ring
Line4: To welcome the Spring;
Line5: The skylark and thrush,
Line6: The birds of the bush,
Line7: Sing louder around
Line8: To the bells' cheerful sound;
Line9: While our sports shall be seen
Line10: On the echoing Green.
Line11: Old John, with white hair,
Line12: Does laugh away care,
Line13: Sitting under the oak,
Line14: Among the old folk.
Line15: They laugh at our play,
Line16: And soon they all say,
Line17: "Such, such were the joys
Line18: When we all--girls and boys--
Line19: In our youth-time were seen
Line20: On the echoing Green."
Line21: Till the little ones, weary,
Line22: No more can be merry:
Line23: The sun does descend,
Line24: And our sports have an end.
Line25: Round the laps of their mothers
Line27: Like birds in their nest,
Line28: Are ready for rest,
Line29: And sport no more seen
Line30: On the darkening green.

Name: The Lamb
Line1: Little Lamb, who made thee
Line2: Dost thou know who made thee,
Line3: Gave thee life, and bid thee feed
Line4: By the stream and o'er the mead;
Line5: Gave thee clothing of delight,
Line6: Softest clothing, woolly, bright;
Line7: Gave thee such a tender voice,
Line8: Making all the vales rejoice?
Line9: Little Lamb, who made thee?
Line10: Dost thou know who made thee?
Line11: Little Lamb, I'll tell thee;
Line12: Little Lamb, I'll tell thee:
Line13: He is called by thy name,
Line14: For He calls Himself a Lamb
Line15: He is meek, and He is mild,
Line16: He became a little child.
Line17: I a child, and thou a lamb,
Line18: We are called by His name.
Line19: Little Lamb, God bless thee!
Line20: Little Lamb, God bless thee!

Name: The Little Black Boy
Line1: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
Line2: And Iam black, but oh my soul is white!
Line3: White as an angel is the English child,
Line4: But I am black, as if bereaved of light.
Line5: My mother taught me underneath a tree,
Line6: And, sitting down before the heat of day,
Line7: She took me on her lap and kissed me,
Line8: And, pointed to the east, began to say:
Line9: "Look on the rising sun: there God does live,
Line10: And gives His light, and gives His heat away,
Line11: And flowers and trees and beasts and men receive
Line12: Comfort in morning, joy in the noonday.
Line13: "And we are put on earth a little space,
Line14: That we may learn to bear the beams of love
Line15: And these black bodies and this sunburnt face
Line16: Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.
Line17: "For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear,
Line18: The cloud will vanish, we shall hear His voice,
Line19: Saying, 'Come out from the grove, my love and care
Line20: And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice',"
Line21: Thus did my mother say, and kissed me;
Line22: And thus I say to little English boy.
Line23: When I from black and he from white cloud free,
Line24: And round the tent of God like lambs we joy
Line25: I'll shade him from the heat till he can bear
Line26: To lean in joy upon our Father's knee;
Line27: And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair,
Line28: And be like him, and he will then love me.

Name: The Blossom
Line1: Merry, merry sparrow!
Line2: Under leaves so green
Line3: A happy blossom
Line4: Sees you, swift as arrow,
Line5: Seek your cradle narrow,
Line6: Near my bosom.
Line7: Pretty, pretty robin!
Line8: Under leaves so green
Line9: A happy blossom
Line10: Hears you sobbing, sobbing,
Line11: Pretty, pretty robin,
Line12: Near my bosom.

Name: The Chimney Sweeper
Line1: When my mother died I was very young,
Line2: And my father sold me while yet my tongue
Line3: Could scarcely cry "Weep! weep! weep! weep!"
Line4: So your chimneys I sweep, and in soot I sleep.
Line5: There's little Tom Dacre, who cried when his head,
Line6: That curled like a lamb's back, was shaved; so I said,
Line7: "Hush, Tom! never mind it, for, when your head's bare,
Line8: You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair."
Line9: And so he was quiet, and that very night,
Line10: As Tom was a-sleeping, he had such a sight!--
Line11: That thousands of sweepers, Dick, Joe, Ned, and Jack,
Line12: Were all of them locked up in coffins of black.
Line13: And by came an angel, who had a bright key,
Line14: And he opened the coffins, and let them all free;
Line15: Then down a green plain, leaping, laughing, they run,
Line16: And wash in a river, and shine in the sun.
Line17: Then naked and white, all their bags left behind,
Line18: They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind;
Line19: And the Angel told Tom, if he'd be a good boy,
Line20: He'd have God for his father, and never want joy.
Line21: And so Tom awoke, and we rose in the dark,
Line22: And got with our bags and our brushes to work.
Line23: Though the morning was cold, Tom was happy and warm:
Line24: So, if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

Name: The Little Boy Lost
Line1: "Father, father, where are you going?
Line2: Oh do not walk so fast!
Line3: Speak, father, speak to your little boy,
Line4: Or else I shall be lost."
Line5: The night was dark, no father was there,
Line6: The child was wet with dew;
Line7: The mire was deep, and the child did weep,
Line8: And away the vapour flew.

Name: The Little Boy Found
Line1: The little boy lost in the lonely fen,
Line2: Led by the wandering light,
Line3: Began to cry, but God, ever nigh,
Line4: Appeared like his father, in white.
Line5: He kissed the child, and by the hand led,
Line6: And to his mother brought,
Line7: Who in sorrow pale, through the lonely dale,
Line8: The little boy weeping sought.

Name: Laughing Song
Line1: When the green woods laugh with the voice of joy,
Line2: And the dimpling stream runs laughing by;
Line3: When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
Line4: And the green hill laughs with the noise of it;
Line5: when the meadows laugh with lively green,
Line6: And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,
Line7: When Mary and Susan and Emily
Line8: With their sweet round mouths sing "Ha, ha he!"
Line9: When the painted birds laugh in the shade,
Line10: Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread:
Line11: Come live, and be merry, and join with me,
Line12: To sing the sweet chorus of "Ha, ha, he!"

Name: Asong
Line1: Sweet dreams, form a shade
Line2: O'er my lovely infant's head!
Line3: Sweet dreams of pleasant streams
Line4: By happy, silent, moony beams!
Line5: Sweet Sleep, with soft down
Line6: Weave thy brows an infant crown
Line7: Sweet Sleep, angel mild,
Line8: Hover o'er my happy child!
Line9: Sweet smiles, in the night
Line10: Hover over my delight!
Line11: Sweet smiles, mother's smile,
Line12: All the livelong night beguile.
Line13: Sweet moans, dovelike sighs,
Line14: Chase not slumber from thine eyes!
Line15: Sweet moan, sweeter smile,
Line16: All the dovelike moans beguile.
Line17: Sleep, sleep, happy child!
Line18: All creation slept and smiled.
Line19: Sleep, sleep, happy sleep,
Line20: While o'er thee doth mother weep.
Line21: Sweet babe, in thy face
Line22: Holy image I can trace;
Line23: Sweet babe, once like thee
Line24: Thy Maker lay, and wept for me:
Line25: Wept for me, for thee, for all,
Line26: When He was an infant small.
Line27: Thou His image ever see,
Line28: Heavenly face that smiles on thee!
Line29: Smiles on thee, on me, on all,
Line30: Who became an infant small;
Line31: Infant smiles are his own smiles;
Line32: Heaven and earth to peace beguiles.

Name: Divine Image
Line1: To Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,
Line2: All pray in their distress,
Line3: And to these virtues of delight
Line4: Return their thankfulness.
Line5: For Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,
Line6: Is God our Father dear;
Line7: And Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,
Line8: Is man, his child and care.
Line9: For Mercy has a human heart
Line10: Pity, a human face;
Line11: And Love, the human form divine;
Line12: And Peace, the human dress.
Line13: Then every man, of every clime,
Line14: That prays in his distress,
Line15: Prays to the human form divine:
Line16: Love, Mercy, Pity, Peace.
Line17: And all must love the human form,
Line18: In heathen, Turk, or Jew.
Line19: Where Mercy, Love, and Pity dwell,
Line20: There God is dwelling too.

Name: Holy Thursday
Line1: 'Twas on a Holy Thursday, their innocent faces clean,
Line2: Came children walking two and two, in read, and blue, and green:
Line3: Grey-headed beadles walked before, with wands as white as snow,
Line4: Till into the high dome of Paul's they like Thames waters flow.
Line5: Oh what a multitude they seemed, these flowers of London town!
Line6: Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own.
Line7: The hum of multitudes was there, but multitudes of lambs,
Line8: Thousands of little boys and girls raising their innocent hands.
Line9: Now like a mighty wild they raise to heaven the voice of song,
Line10: Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among:
Line11: Beneath them sit the aged man, wise guardians of the poor.
Line12: Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door.

Name: Night
Line1: The sun descending in the west,
Line2: The evening star does shine;
Line3: The birds are silent in their nest,
Line4: And I must seek for mine.
Line5: The moon, like a flower
Line6: In heaven's high bower,
Line7: With silent delight,
Line8: Sits and smiles on the night.
Line9: Farewell, green fields and happy grove,
Line10: Where flocks have ta'en delight.
Line11: Where lambs have nibbled, silent move
Line12: The feet of angels bright;
Line13: Unseen they pour blessing,
Line14: And joy without ceasing,
Line15: On each bud and blossom,
Line16: And each sleeping bosom.
Line17: They look in every thoughtless nest
Line18: Where birds are covered warm;
Line19: They visit caves of every beast,
Line20: To keep them all from harm:
Line21: If they see any weeping
Line22: That should have been sleeping,
Line23: They pour sleep on their head,
Line24: And sit down by their bed.
Line25: When wolves and tigers howl for prey,
Line27: Seeking to drive their thirst away,
Line28: And keep them from the sheep.
Line29: But, if they rush dreadful,
Line30: The angels, most heedful,
Line31: Receive each mild spirit,
Line32: New worlds to inherit.
Line33: And there the lion's ruddy eyes
Line34: Shall flow with tears of gold:
Line35: And pitying the tender cries,
Line36: And walking round the fold:
Line37: Saying: "Wrath by His meekness,
Line38: And, by His health, sickness,
Line39: Are driven away
Line40: From our immortal day.
Line41: "And now beside thee, bleating lamb,
Line42: I can lie down and sleep,
Line43: Or think on Him who bore thy name,
Line44: Graze after thee, and weep.
Line46: My bright mane for ever
Line47: Shall shine like the gold,
Line48: As I guard o'er the fold."

Name: Spring
Line1: Sound the flute!
Line2: Now it's mute!
Line3: Bird's delight,
Line4: Day and night,
Line5: Nightingale,
Line6: In the dale,
Line7: Lark in sky,--
Line8: Merrily,
Line9: Merrily merrily, to welcome in the year.
Line10: Little boy,
Line11: Full of joy;
Line12: Little girl,
Line13: Sweet and small;
Line14: Cock does crow,
Line15: So do you;
Line16: Merry voice,
Line17: Infant noise;
Line18: Merrily, merrily, to welcome in the year.
Line19: Little lamb,
Line20: Here I am;
Line21: Come and lick
Line22: My white neck;
Line23: Let me pull
Line24: Your soft wool;
Line25: Let me kiss
Line27: Merrily, merrily, to welcome in the year.

Name: Nurse's Song
Line1: When the voices of children are heard on the green,
Line2: And laughing is heard on the hill,
Line3: My heart is at rest within my breast,
Line4: And everything else is still.
Line5: "Then come home, my children, the sun is gone down,
Line6: And the dews of night arise;
Line7: Come, come, leave off play, and let us away,
Line8: Till the morning appears in the skies."
Line9: "No, no, let us play, for it is yet day,
Line10: And we cannot go to sleep;
Line11: Besides, in the sky the little birds fly,
Line12: And the hills are all covered with sheep."
Line13: "Well, well, go and play till the light fades away,
Line14: And then go home to bed."
Line15: The little ones leaped, and shouted, and laughed,
Line16: And all the hills echoed.

Name: Infant Joy
Line1: "I have no name;
Line2: I am but two days old."
Line3: What shall I call thee?
Line4: "I happy am,
Line5: Joy is my name."
Line6: Sweet joy befall thee!
Line7: Pretty joy!
Line8: Sweet joy, but two days old.
Line9: Sweet Joy I call thee:
Line10: Thou dost smile,
Line11: I sing the while;
Line12: Sweet joy befall thee!

Name: A Dream
Line1: Once a dream did weave a shade
Line2: O'er my angel-guarded bed,
Line3: That an emmet lost its way
Line4: Where on grass methought I lay.
Line5: Troubled, wildered, and forlorn,
Line6: Dark, benighted, travel-worn,
Line7: Over many a tangle spray,
Line8: All heart-broke, I heard her say:
Line9: "Oh my children! do they cry,
Line10: Do they hear their father sigh?
Line11: Now they look abroad to see,
Line12: Now return and weep for me."
Line13: Pitying, I dropped a tear:
Line14: But I saw a glow-worm near,
Line15: Who replied, "What wailing wight
Line16: Calls the watchman of the night?
Line17: "I am set to light the ground,
Line18: While the beetle goes his round:
Line19: Follow now the beetle's hum;
Line20: Little wanderer, hie thee home!"

Name: On Another's Sorrow
Line1: Can I see another's woe,
Line2: And not be in sorrow too?
Line3: Can I see another's grief,
Line4: And not seek for kind relief?
Line5: Can I see a falling tear,
Line6: And not feel my sorrow's share?
Line7: Can a father see his child
Line8: Weep, nor be with sorrow filled?
Line9: Can a mother sit and hear
Line10: An infant groan, an infant fear?
Line11: No, no!never can it be!
Line12: Never, never can it be!
Line13: And can He who smiles on all
Line14: Hear the wren with sorrows small,
Line15: Hear the small bird's grief and care,
Line16: Hear the woes that infants bear--
Line17: And not sit beside the next,
Line18: Pouring pity in their breast,
Line19: And not sit the cradle near,
Line20: Weeping tear on infant's tear?
Line21: And not sit both night and day,
Line22: Wiping all our tears away?
Line23: Oh no! never can it be!
Line24: Never, never can it be!
Line25: He doth give his joy to all:
Line27: He becomes a man of woe,
Line28: He doth feel the sorrow too.
Line29: Think not thou canst sigh a sigh,
Line30: And thy Maker is not by:
Line31: Think not thou canst weep a tear,
Line32: And thy Maker is not near.
Line33: Oh He gives to us his joy,
Line34: That our grief He may destroy:
Line35: Till our grief is fled an gone
Line36: He doth sit by us and moan.

Name: Introduction to Songs of Experience
Line1: Hear the voice of the Bard,
Line2: Who present, past, and future, sees;
Line3: Whose ears have heard
Line4: The Holy Word
Line5: That walked among the ancient tree;
Line6: Calling the lapsed soul,
Line7: And weeping in the evening dew;
Line8: That might control
Line9: The starry pole,
Line10: And fallen, fallen light renew!
Line11: "O Earth, O Earth, return!
Line12: Arise from out the dewy grass!
Line13: Night is worn,
Line14: And the morn
Line15: Rises from the slumbrous mass.
Line16: "Turn away no more;
Line17: Why wilt thou turn away?
Line18: The starry floor,
Line19: The watery shore,
Line20: Are given thee till the break of day."

Name: Earth's Answer
Line1: Earth raised up her head
Line2: From the darkness dread and drear,
Line3: Her light fled,
Line4: Stony, dread,
Line5: And her locks covered with grey despair.
Line6: "Prisoned on watery shore,
Line7: Starry jealousy does keep my den
Line8: Cold and hoar;
Line9: Weeping o'er,
Line10: I hear the father of the ancient men.
Line11: "Selfish father of men!
Line12: Cruel, jealous, selfish fear!
Line13: Can delight,
Line14: Chained in night,
Line15: The virgins of youth and morning bear?
Line16: "Does spring hide its joy,
Line17: When buds and blossoms grow?
Line18: Does the sower
Line19: Sow by night,
Line20: Or the plowman in darkness plough?
Line21: "Break this heavy chain,
Line22: That does freeze my bones around!
Line23: Selfish, vain,
Line24: Eternal bane,
Line25: That free love with bondage bound."

Name: The Clod and the Pebble
Line1: "Love seeketh not itself to please,
Line2: Nor for itself hath any care,
Line3: But for another gives it ease,
Line4: And builds a heaven in hell's despair."
Line5: So sang a little clod of clay,
Line6: Trodden with the cattle's feet,
Line7: But a pebble of the brook
Line8: Warbled out these metres meet:
Line9: "Love seeketh only Self to please,
Line10: To bind another to its delight,
Line11: Joys in another's loss of ease,
Line12: And builds a hell in heaven's despite."

Name: Holy Thursday
Line1: Is this a holy thing to see
Line2: In a rich and fruitful land,--
Line3: Babes reduced to misery,
Line4: Fed with cold and usurous hand?
Line5: Is that trembling cry a song?
Line6: Can it be a song of joy?
Line7: And so many children poor?
Line8: It is a land of poverty!
Line9: And their son does never shine,
Line10: And their fields are bleak and bare,
Line11: And their ways are filled with thorns:
Line12: It is eternal winter there.
Line13: For where'er the sun does shine,
Line14: And where'er the rain does fall,
Line15: Babes should never hunger there,
Line16: Nor poverty the mind appall.

Name: The Little Girl Lost
Line1: In futurity
Line2: I prophetic see
Line3: That the earth from sleep
Line4: (Grave the sentence deep)
Line5: Shall arise, and seek
Line6: for her Maker meek;
Line7: And the desert wild
Line8: Become a garden mild.
Line9: In the southern clime,
Line10: Where the summer's prime
Line11: Never fades away,
Line12: Lovely Lyca lay.
Line13: Seven summers old
Line14: Lovely Lyca told.
Line15: She had wandered long,
Line16: Hearing wild birds' song.
Line17: "Sweet sleep, come to me
Line18: Underneath this tree;
Line19: Do father, mother, weep?
Line20: Where can Lyca sleep?
Line21: "Lost in desert wild
Line22: Is your little child.
Line23: How can Lyca sleep
Line24: If her mother weep?
Line25: "If her heart does ache,
Line27: If my mother sleep,
Line28: Lyca shall not weep.
Line29: "Frowning, frowning night,
Line30: O'er this desert bright
Line31: Let thy moon arise,
Line32: While I close my eyes."
Line33: Sleeping Lyca lay
Line34: While the beasts of prey,
Line35: Come from caverns deep,
Line36: Viewed the maid asleep.
Line37: The kingly lion stood,
Line38: And the virgin viewed:
Line39: Then he gambolled round
Line40: O'er the hallowed ground.
Line41: Leopards, tigers, play
Line42: Round her as she lay;
Line43: While the lion old
Line44: Bowed his mane of gold,
Line46: And upon her neck,
Line47: From his eyes of flame,
Line48: Ruby tears there came;
Line49: While the lioness
Line50: Loosed her slender dress,

Name: The Little Girl Found
Line1: All the night in woe
Line2: Lyca's parents go
Line3: Over valleys deep,
Line4: While the deserts weep.
Line5: Tired and woe-begone,
Line6: Hoarse with making moan,
Line7: Arm in arm, seven days
Line8: They traced the desert ways.
Line9: Seven nights they sleep
Line10: Among shadows deep,
Line11: And dream they see their child
Line12: Starved in desert wild.
Line13: Pale through pathless ways
Line14: The fancied image strays,
Line15: Famished, weeping, weak,
Line16: With hollow piteous shriek.
Line17: Rising from unrest,
Line18: The trembling woman pressed
Line19: With feet of weary woe;
Line20: She could no further go.
Line21: In his arms he bore
Line22: Her, armed with sorrow sore;
Line23: Till before their way
Line24: A couching lion lay.
Line25: Turning back was vain:
Line27: Bore them to the ground,
Line28: Then he stalked around,
Line29: Smelling to his prey;
Line30: But their fears allay
Line31: When he licks their hands,
Line32: And silent by them stands.
Line33: They look upon his eyes,
Line34: Filled with deep surprise;
Line35: And wondering behold
Line36: A spirit armed in gold.
Line37: On his head a crown,
Line38: On his shoulders down
Line39: Flowed his golden hair.
Line40: Gone was all their care.
Line41: "Follow me," he said;
Line42: "Weep not for the maid;
Line43: In my palace deep,
Line44: Lyca lies asleep."
Line46: Where the vision led,
Line47: And saw their sleeping child
Line48: Among tigers wild.
Line49: To this day they dwell
Line50: In a lonely dell,

Name: The Chimney Sweeper
Line1: A little black thing in the snow,
Line2: Crying "weep! weep!" in notes of woe!
Line3: "Where are thy father and mother? Say!"--
Line4: "They are both gone up to the church to pray.
Line5: "Because I was happy upon the heath,
Line6: And smiled among the winter's snow,
Line7: They clothed me in the clothes of death,
Line8: And taught me to sing the notes of woe.
Line9: "And because I am happy and dance and sing,
Line10: They think they have done me no injury,
Line11: And are gone to praise God and his priest and king,
Line12: Who make up a heaven of our misery."

Name: Nurse's Song II
Line1: When voices of children are heard on the green,
Line2: And whisperings are in the dale,
Line3: The days of my youth rise fresh in my mind,
Line4: My face turns green and pale.
Line5: Then come home, my children, the sun is gone down,
Line6: And the dews of night arise;
Line7: Your spring and your day are wasted in play,
Line8: And your winter and night in disguise.

Name: The Sick Rose
Line1: O rose, thou art sick!
Line2: The invisible worm,
Line3: That flies in the night,
Line4: In the howling storm,
Line5: Has found out thy bed
Line6: Of crimson joy,
Line7: And his dark secret love
Line8: Does thy life destroy.

Name: The Fly
Line1: Little Fly,
Line2: Thy summer's play
Line3: My thoughtless hand
Line4: Has brushed away.
Line5: Am not I
Line6: A fly like thee?
Line7: Or art not thou
Line8: A man like me?
Line9: For I dance
Line10: And drink, and sing,
Line11: Till some blind hand
Line12: Shall brush my wing.
Line13: If thought is life
Line14: And strength and breath
Line15: And the want
Line16: Of thought is death;
Line17: Then am I
Line18: A happy fly,
Line19: If I live,
Line20: Or if I die.

Name: The Angel
Line1: I dreamt a dream!What can it mean?
Line2: And that I was a maiden Queen
Line3: Guarded by an Angel mild:
Line4: Witless woe was ne'er beguiled!
Line5: And I wept both night and day,
Line6: And he wiped my tears away;
Line7: And I wept both day and night,
Line8: And hid from him my heart's delight.
Line9: So he took his wings, and fled;
Line10: Then the morn blushed rosy red.
Line11: I dried my tears, and armed my fears
Line12: With ten-thousand shields and spears.
Line13: Soon my Angel came again;
Line14: I was armed, he came in vain;
Line15: For the time of youth was fled,
Line16: And grey hairs were on my head.

Name: The Tyger
Line1: Tyger, tyger, burning bright
Line2: In the forests of the night,
Line3: What immortal hand or eye
Line4: Could frame thy fearful symmetry?
Line5: In what distant deeps or skies
Line6: Burnt the fire of thine eyes?
Line7: On what wings dare he aspire?
Line8: What the hand dare seize the fire?
Line9: And what shoulder and what art
Line10: Could twist the sinews of thy heart?
Line11: And, when thy heart began to beat,
Line12: What dread hand and what dread feet?
Line13: What the hammer?what the chain?
Line14: In what furnace was thy brain?
Line15: What the anvil? what dread grasp
Line16: Dare its deadly terrors clasp?
Line17: When the stars threw down their spears,
Line18: And watered heaven with their tears,
Line19: Did he smile his work to see?
Line20: Did he who made the lamb make thee?
Line21: Tyger, tyger, burning bright
Line22: In the forests of the night,
Line23: What immortal hand or eye
Line24: Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?

Name: My Pretty Rose Tree
Line1: A flower was offered to me,
Line2: Such a flower as May never bore;
Line3: But I said "I've a pretty rose tree,"
Line4: And I passed the sweet flower o'er.

Name: Annabel Lee
Line1: It was many and many a year ago,
Line2: In a kingdom by the sea,
Line3: That a maiden there lived whom you may know
Line4: By the name of Annabel Lee;
Line5: And this maiden she lived with no other thought
Line6: Than to love and be loved by me.
Line7: I was a child and she was a child,
Line8: In this kingdom by the sea,
Line9: But we loved with a love that was more than love—
Line10: I and my Annabel Lee—
Line11: With a love that the wingèd seraphs of Heaven
Line12: Coveted her and me.
Line13: And this was the reason that, long ago,
Line14: In this kingdom by the sea,
Line15: A wind blew out of a cloud, chilling
Line16: My beautiful Annabel Lee;
Line17: So that her highborn kinsmen came
Line18: And bore her away from me,
Line19: To shut her up in a sepulchre
Line20: In this kingdom by the sea.
Line21: The angels, not half so happy in Heaven,
Line22: Went envying her and me—
Line23: Yes!—that was the reason (as all men know,
Line24: In this kingdom by the sea)
Line25: That the wind came out of the cloud by night,
Line26: Chilling and killing my Annabel Lee.
Line27: But our love it was stronger by far than the love
Line28: Of those who were older than we—
Line29: Of many far wiser than we—
Line30: And neither the angels in Heaven above
Line31: Nor the demons down under the sea
Line32: Can ever dissever my soul from the soul
Line33: Of the beautiful Annabel Lee;
Line34: For the moon never beams, without bringing me dreams
Line35: Of the beautiful Annabel Lee;
Line36: And the stars never rise, but I feel the bright eyes
Line37: Of the beautiful Annabel Lee;
Line38: And so, all the night-tide, I lie down by the side
Line39: Of my darling—my darling—my life and my bride,
Line40: In her sepulchre there by the sea—
Line41: In her tomb by the sounding sea.

Name: The Raven
Line1: Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,
Line2: Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—
Line3: While I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping,
Line4: As of some one gently rapping, rapping at my chamber door.
Line5: “’Tis some visitor,” I muttered, “tapping at my chamber door—
Line6: Only this and nothing more.”
Line7: Ah, distinctly I remember it was in the bleak December;
Line8: And each separate dying ember wrought its ghost upon the floor.
Line9: Eagerly I wished the morrow;—vainly I had sought to borrow
Line10: From my books surcease of sorrow—sorrow for the lost Lenore—
Line11: For the rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore—
Line12: Nameless here for evermore.
Line13: And the silken, sad, uncertain rustling of each purple curtain
Line14: Thrilled me—filled me with fantastic terrors never felt before;
Line15: So that now, to still the beating of my heart, I stood repeating
Line16: “’Tis some visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door—
Line17: Some late visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door;—
Line18: This it is and nothing more.”
Line19: Presently my soul grew stronger; hesitating then no longer,
Line20: “Sir,” said I, “or Madam, truly your forgiveness I implore;
Line21: But the fact is I was napping, and so gently you came rapping,
Line22: And so faintly you came tapping, tapping at my chamber door,
Line23: That I scarce was sure I heard you”—here I opened wide the door;—
Line24: Darkness there and nothing more.
Line25: Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,
Line26: Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before;
Line27: But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token,
Line28: And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, “Lenore?”
Line29: This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, “Lenore!”—
Line30: Merely this and nothing more.
Line31: Back into the chamber turning, all my soul within me burning,
Line32: Soon again I heard a tapping somewhat louder than before.
Line33: “Surely,” said I, “surely that is something at my window lattice;
Line34: Let me see, then, what thereat is, and this mystery explore—
Line35: Let my heart be still a moment and this mystery explore;—
Line36: ’Tis the wind and nothing more!”
Line37: Open here I flung the shutter, when, with many a flirt and flutter,
Line38: In there stepped a stately Raven of the saintly days of yore;
Line39: Not the least obeisance made he; not a minute stopped or stayed he;
Line40: But, with mien of lord or lady, perched above my chamber door—
Line41: Perched upon a bust of Pallas just above my chamber door—
Line42: Perched, and sat, and nothing more.
Line43: Then this ebony bird beguiling my sad fancy into smiling,
Line44: By the grave and stern decorum of the countenance it wore,
Line45: “Though thy crest be shorn and shaven, thou,” I said, “art sure no craven,
Line46: Ghastly grim and ancient Raven wandering from the Nightly shore—
Line47: Tell me what thy lordly name is on the Night’s Plutonian shore!”
Line48: Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”
Line49: Much I marvelled this ungainly fowl to hear discourse so plainly,
Line50: Though its answer little meaning—little relevancy bore;

Name: The Bells
Line1: Hear the sledges with the bells--
Line2: Silver bells!
Line3: What a world of merriment their melody foretells!
Line4: How they tinkle, tinkle, tinkle,
Line5: In their icy air of night!
Line6: While the stars, that oversprinkle
Line7: All the heavens, seem to twinkle
Line8: With a crystalline delight;
Line9: Keeping time, time, time,
Line10: In a sort of Runic rhyme,
Line11: To the tintinnabulation that so musically wells
Line12: From the bells, bells, bells, bells,
Line13: Bells, bells, bells--
Line14: From the jingling and the tinkling of the bells.
Line15: Hear the mellow wedding bells,
Line16: Golden bells!
Line17: What a world of happiness their harmony foretells!
Line18: Through the balmy air of night
Line19: How they ring out their delight!
Line20: From the molten golden-notes,
Line21: And all in tune,
Line22: What a liquid ditty floats
Line23: To the turtle-dove that listens, while she gloats
Line24: On the moon!
Line25: Oh, from out the sounding cells,
Line26: What a gush of euphony voluminously wells!
Line27: How it swells!
Line28: How it dwells
Line29: On the future! how it tells
Line30: Of the rapture that impels
Line31: To the swinging and the ringing
Line32: Of the bells, bells, bells,
Line33: Of the bells, bells, bells, bells,
Line34: Bells, bells, bells--
Line35: To the rhyming and the chiming of the bells!
Line36: Hear the loud alarum bells--
Line37: Brazen bells!
Line38: What a tale of terror now their turbulency tells!
Line39: In the startled ear of night
Line40: How they scream out their affright!
Line41: Too much horrified to speak,
Line42: They can only shriek, shriek,
Line43: Out of tune,
Line44: In a clamorous appealing to the mercy of the fire,
Line45: In a mad expostulation with the deaf and frantic fire
Line46: Leaping higher, higher, higher,
Line47: With a desperate desire,
Line48: And a resolute endeavor
Line49: Now--now to sit or never,
Line50: By the side of the pale-faced moon.

Name: Ulalume
Line1: ULALUME.
Line2: The skies they were ashen and sober;
Line3: The leaves they were crisped and sere--
Line4: The leaves they were withering and sere;
Line5: It was night in the lonesome October
Line6: Of my most immemorial year;
Line7: It was hard by the dim lake of Auber,
Line8: In the misty mid region of Weir--
Line9: It was down by the dank tarn of Auber,
Line10: In the ghoul-haunted woodland of Weir.
Line11: Here once, through an alley Titanic.
Line12: Of cypress, I roamed with my Soul--
Line13: Of cypress, with Psyche, my Soul.
Line14: These were days when my heart was volcanic
Line15: As the scoriac rivers that roll--
Line16: As the lavas that restlessly roll
Line17: Their sulphurous currents down Yaanek
Line18: In the ultimate climes of the pole--
Line19: That groan as they roll down Mount Yaanek
Line20: In the realms of the boreal pole.
Line21: Our talk had been serious and sober,
Line22: But our thoughts they were palsied and sere--
Line23: Our memories were treacherous and sere--
Line24: For we knew not the month was October,
Line25: And we marked not the night of the year--
Line26: (Ah, night of all nights in the year!)
Line27: We noted not the dim lake of Auber--
Line28: (Though once we had journeyed down here)--
Line29: Remembered not the dank tarn of Auber,
Line30: Nor the ghoul-haunted woodland of Weir.
Line31: And now as the night was senescent
Line32: And star-dials pointed to morn--
Line33: As the sun-dials hinted of morn--
Line34: At the end of our path a liquescent
Line35: And nebulous lustre was born,
Line36: Out of which a miraculous crescent
Line37: Arose with a duplicate horn--
Line38: Astarte's bediamonded crescent
Line39: Distinct with its duplicate horn.
Line40: And I said--"She is warmer than Dian:
Line41: She rolls through an ether of sighs--
Line42: She revels in a region of sighs:
Line43: She has seen that the tears are not dry on
Line44: These cheeks, where the worm never dies,
Line45: And has come past the stars of the Lion
Line46: To point us the path to the skies--
Line47: To the Lethean peace of the skies--
Line48: Come up, in despite of the Lion,
Line49: To shine on us with her bright eyes--
Line50: Come up through the lair of the Lion,

Name: To Helen
Line1: I saw thee once--once only--years ago:
Line2: I must not say _how_ many--but _not_ many.
Line3: It was a July midnight; and from out
Line4: A full-orbed moon, that, like thine own soul, soaring,
Line5: Sought a precipitate pathway up through heaven,
Line6: There fell a silvery-silken veil of light,
Line7: With quietude, and sultriness and slumber,
Line8: Upon the upturn'd faces of a thousand
Line9: Roses that grew in an enchanted garden,
Line10: Where no wind dared to stir, unless on tiptoe--
Line11: Fell on the upturn'd faces of these roses
Line12: That gave out, in return for the love-light,
Line13: Their odorous souls in an ecstatic death--
Line14: Fell on the upturn'd faces of these roses
Line15: That smiled and died in this parterre, enchanted
Line16: By thee, and by the poetry of thy presence.
Line17: Clad all in white, upon a violet bank
Line18: I saw thee half-reclining; while the moon
Line19: Fell on the upturn'd faces of the roses,
Line20: And on thine own, upturn'd--alas, in sorrow!
Line21: Was it not Fate, that, on this July midnight--
Line22: Was it not Fate (whose name is also Sorrow),
Line23: That bade me pause before that garden-gate,
Line24: To breathe the incense of those slumbering roses?
Line25: No footstep stirred: the hated world all slept,
Line26: Save only thee and me--(O Heaven!--O God!
Line27: How my heart beats in coupling those two words!)--
Line28: Save only thee and me. I paused--I looked--
Line29: And in an instant all things disappeared.
Line30: (Ah, bear in mind this garden was enchanted!)
Line31: The pearly lustre of the moon went out:
Line32: The mossy banks and the meandering paths,
Line33: The happy flowers and the repining trees,
Line34: Were seen no more: the very roses' odors
Line35: Died in the arms of the adoring airs.
Line36: All--all expired save thee--save less than thou:
Line37: Save only the divine light in thine eyes--
Line38: Save but the soul in thine uplifted eyes.
Line39: I saw but them--they were the world to me.
Line40: I saw but them--saw only them for hours--
Line41: Saw only them until the moon went down.
Line42: What wild heart-histories seemed to lie unwritten
Line43: Upon those crystalline, celestial spheres!
Line44: How dark a woe! yet how sublime a hope!
Line45: How silently serene a sea of pride!
Line46: How daring an ambition! yet how deep--
Line47: How fathomless a capacity for love!
Line48: But now, at length, dear Dian sank from sight,
Line49: Into a western couch of thunder-cloud;
Line50: And thou, a ghost, amid the entombing trees

Name: For Annie
Line1: Thank Heaven! the crisis--
Line2: The danger is past,
Line3: And the lingering illness
Line4: Is over at last--
Line5: And the fever called "Living"
Line6: Is conquered at last.
Line7: Sadly, I know,
Line8: I am shorn of my strength,
Line9: And no muscle I move
Line10: As I lie at full length--
Line11: But no matter!--I feel
Line12: I am better at length.
Line13: And I rest so composedly,
Line14: Now in my bed,
Line15: That any beholder
Line16: Might fancy me dead--
Line17: Might start at beholding me
Line18: Thinking me dead.
Line19: The moaning and groaning,
Line20: The sighing and sobbing,
Line21: Are quieted now,
Line22: With that horrible throbbing
Line23: At heart:--ah, that horrible,
Line24: Horrible throbbing!
Line25: The sickness--the nausea--
Line27: Have ceased, with the fever
Line28: That maddened my brain--
Line29: With the fever called "Living"
Line30: That burned in my brain.
Line31: And oh! of all tortures
Line32: _That_ torture the worst
Line33: Has abated--the terrible
Line34: Torture of thirst,
Line35: For the naphthaline river
Line36: Of Passion accurst:--
Line37: I have drank of a water
Line38: That quenches all thirst:--
Line39: Of a water that flows,
Line40: With a lullaby sound,
Line41: From a spring but a very few
Line42: Feet under ground--
Line43: From a cavern not very far
Line44: Down under ground.
Line46: Be foolishly said
Line47: That my room it is gloomy
Line48: And narrow my bed--
Line49: For man never slept
Line50: In a different bed;

Name: El Dorado
Line1: Gaily bedight,
Line2: A gallant knight,
Line3: In sunshine and in shadow,
Line4: Had journeyed long,
Line5: Singing a song,
Line6: In search of Eldorado.
Line7: But he grew old--
Line8: This knight so bold--
Line9: And o'er his heart a shadow
Line10: Fell as he found
Line11: No spot of ground
Line12: That looked like Eldorado.
Line13: And, as his strength
Line14: Failed him at length,
Line15: He met a pilgrim shadow--
Line16: "Shadow," said he,
Line17: "Where can it be--
Line18: This land of Eldorado?"
Line19: "Over the Mountains
Line20: Of the Moon,
Line21: Down the Valley of the Shadow,
Line22: Ride, boldly ride,"
Line23: The shade replied,
Line24: "If you seek for Eldorado!"

Name: A Dream Within a Dream
Line1: Take this kiss upon the brow!
Line2: And, in parting from you now,
Line3: Thus much let me avow--
Line4: You are not wrong, who deem
Line5: That my days have been a dream:
Line6: Yet if hope has flown away
Line7: In a night, or in a day,
Line8: In a vision or in none,
Line9: Is it therefore the less _gone_?
Line10: _All_ that we see or seem
Line11: Is but a dream within a dream.
Line12: I stand amid the roar
Line13: Of a surf-tormented shore,
Line14: And I hold within my hand
Line15: Grains of the golden sand--
Line16: How few! yet how they creep
Line17: Through my fingers to the deep
Line18: While I weep--while I weep!
Line19: O God! can I not grasp
Line20: Them with a tighter clasp?
Line21: O God! can I not save
Line22: _One_ from the pitiless wave?
Line23: Is _all_ that we see or seem
Line24: But a dream within a dream?

Name: Art
Line1: Give to barrows, trays, and pans
Line2: Grace and glimmer of romance;
Line3: Bring the moonlight into noon
Line4: Hid in gleaming piles of stone;
Line5: On the city's paved street
Line6: Plant gardens lined with lilacs sweet;
Line7: Let spouting fountains cool the air,
Line8: Singing in the sun-baked square;
Line9: Let statue, picture, park, and hall,
Line10: Ballad, flag, and festival,
Line11: The past restore, the day adorn,
Line12: And make to-morrow a new morn.
Line13: So shall the drudge in dusty frock
Line14: Spy behind the city clock
Line15: Retinues of airy kings,
Line16: Skirts of angels, starry wings,
Line17: His fathers shining in bright fables,
Line18: His children fed at heavenly tables.
Line19: 'T is the privilege of Art
Line20: Thus to play its cheerful part,
Line21: Man on earth to acclimate,
Line22: And bend the exile to his fate,
Line23: And, moulded of one element
Line24: With the days and firmament,
Line25: Teach him on these as stairs to climb,
Line26: And live on even terms with Time;
Line27: Whilst upper life the slender rill
Line28: Of human sense doth overfill.

Name: Go a Roving
Line1: So, we'll go no more a roving
Line2: So late into the night,
Line3: Though the heart be still as loving,
Line4: And the moon be still as bright.
Line5: For the sword outwears its sheath,
Line6: And the soul wears out the breast,
Line7: And the heart must pause to breathe,
Line8: And love itself have rest.
Line9: Though the night was made for loving,
Line10: And the day returns too soon,
Line11: Yet we'll go no more a roving
Line12: By the light of the moon.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 1
Line1: From fairest creatures we desire increase,
Line2: That thereby beauty's rose might never die,
Line3: But as the riper should by time decease,
Line4: His tender heir might bear his memory:
Line5: But thou, contracted to thine own bright eyes,
Line6: Feed'st thy light'st flame with self-substantial fuel,
Line7: Making a famine where abundance lies,
Line8: Thyself thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel.
Line9: Thou that art now the world's fresh ornament
Line10: And only herald to the gaudy spring,
Line11: Within thine own bud buriest thy content
Line12: And, tender churl, makest waste in niggarding.
Line13: Pity the world, or else this glutton be,
Line14: To eat the world's due, by the grave and thee.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 2
Line1: When forty winters shall beseige thy brow,
Line2: And dig deep trenches in thy beauty's field,
Line3: Thy youth's proud livery, so gazed on now,
Line4: Will be a tatter'd weed, of small worth held:
Line5: Then being ask'd where all thy beauty lies,
Line6: Where all the treasure of thy lusty days,
Line7: To say, within thine own deep-sunken eyes,
Line8: Were an all-eating shame and thriftless praise.
Line9: How much more praise deserved thy beauty's use,
Line10: If thou couldst answer 'This fair child of mine
Line11: Shall sum my count and make my old excuse,'
Line12: Proving his beauty by succession thine!
Line13: This were to be new made when thou art old,
Line14: And see thy blood warm when thou feel'st it cold.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 3
Line1: Look in thy glass, and tell the face thou viewest
Line2: Now is the time that face should form another;
Line3: Whose fresh repair if now thou not renewest,
Line4: Thou dost beguile the world, unbless some mother.
Line5: For where is she so fair whose unear'd womb
Line6: Disdains the tillage of thy husbandry?
Line7: Or who is he so fond will be the tomb
Line8: Of his self-love, to stop posterity?
Line9: Thou art thy mother's glass, and she in thee
Line10: Calls back the lovely April of her prime:
Line11: So thou through windows of thine age shall see
Line12: Despite of wrinkles this thy golden time.
Line13: But if thou live, remember'd not to be,
Line14: Die single, and thine image dies with thee.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 4
Line1: Unthrifty loveliness, why dost thou spend
Line2: Upon thyself thy beauty's legacy?
Line3: Nature's bequest gives nothing but doth lend,
Line4: And being frank she lends to those are free.
Line5: Then, beauteous niggard, why dost thou abuse
Line6: The bounteous largess given thee to give?
Line7: Profitless usurer, why dost thou use
Line8: So great a sum of sums, yet canst not live?
Line9: For having traffic with thyself alone,
Line10: Thou of thyself thy sweet self dost deceive.
Line11: Then how, when nature calls thee to be gone,
Line12: What acceptable audit canst thou leave?
Line13: Thy unused beauty must be tomb'd with thee,
Line14: Which, used, lives th' executor to be.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 5
Line1: Those hours, that with gentle work did frame
Line2: The lovely gaze where every eye doth dwell,
Line3: Will play the tyrants to the very same
Line4: And that unfair which fairly doth excel:
Line5: For never-resting time leads summer on
Line6: To hideous winter and confounds him there;
Line7: Sap cheque'd with frost and lusty leaves quite gone,
Line8: Beauty o'ersnow'd and bareness every where:
Line9: Then, were not summer's distillation left,
Line10: A liquid prisoner pent in walls of glass,
Line11: Beauty's effect with beauty were bereft,
Line12: Nor it nor no remembrance what it was:
Line13: But flowers distill'd though they with winter meet,
Line14: Leese but their show; their substance still lives sweet.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 6
Line1: Then let not winter's ragged hand deface
Line2: In thee thy summer, ere thou be distill'd:
Line3: Make sweet some vial; treasure thou some place
Line4: With beauty's treasure, ere it be self-kill'd.
Line5: That use is not forbidden usury,
Line6: Which happies those that pay the willing loan;
Line7: That's for thyself to breed another thee,
Line8: Or ten times happier, be it ten for one;
Line9: Ten times thyself were happier than thou art,
Line10: If ten of thine ten times refigured thee:
Line11: Then what could death do, if thou shouldst depart,
Line12: Leaving thee living in posterity?
Line13: Be not self-will'd, for thou art much too fair
Line14: To be death's conquest and make worms thine heir.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 7
Line1: Lo! in the orient when the gracious light
Line2: Lifts up his burning head, each under eye
Line3: Doth homage to his new-appearing sight,
Line4: Serving with looks his sacred majesty;
Line5: And having climb'd the steep-up heavenly hill,
Line6: Resembling strong youth in his middle age,
Line7: yet mortal looks adore his beauty still,
Line8: Attending on his golden pilgrimage;
Line9: But when from highmost pitch, with weary car,
Line10: Like feeble age, he reeleth from the day,
Line11: The eyes, 'fore duteous, now converted are
Line12: From his low tract and look another way:
Line13: So thou, thyself out-going in thy noon,
Line14: Unlook'd on diest, unless thou get a son.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 8
Line1: Music to hear, why hear'st thou music sadly?
Line2: Sweets with sweets war not, joy delights in joy.
Line3: Why lovest thou that which thou receivest not gladly,
Line4: Or else receivest with pleasure thine annoy?
Line5: If the true concord of well-tuned sounds,
Line6: By unions married, do offend thine ear,
Line7: They do but sweetly chide thee, who confounds
Line8: In singleness the parts that thou shouldst bear.
Line9: Mark how one string, sweet husband to another,
Line10: Strikes each in each by mutual ordering,
Line11: Resembling sire and child and happy mother
Line12: Who all in one, one pleasing note do sing:
Line13: Whose speechless song, being many, seeming one,
Line14: Sings this to thee: 'thou single wilt prove none.'

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 9
Line1: Is it for fear to wet a widow's eye
Line2: That thou consumest thyself in single life?
Line3: Ah! if thou issueless shalt hap to die.
Line4: The world will wail thee, like a makeless wife;
Line5: The world will be thy widow and still weep
Line6: That thou no form of thee hast left behind,
Line7: When every private widow well may keep
Line8: By children's eyes her husband's shape in mind.
Line9: Look, what an unthrift in the world doth spend
Line10: Shifts but his place, for still the world enjoys it;
Line11: But beauty's waste hath in the world an end,
Line12: And kept unused, the user so destroys it.
Line13: No love toward others in that bosom sits
Line14: That on himself such murderous shame commits.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 10
Line1: For shame! deny that thou bear'st love to any,
Line2: Who for thyself art so unprovident.
Line3: Grant, if thou wilt, thou art beloved of many,
Line4: But that thou none lovest is most evident;
Line5: For thou art so possess'd with murderous hate
Line6: That 'gainst thyself thou stick'st not to conspire.
Line7: Seeking that beauteous roof to ruinate
Line8: Which to repair should be thy chief desire.
Line9: O, change thy thought, that I may change my mind!
Line10: Shall hate be fairer lodged than gentle love?
Line11: Be, as thy presence is, gracious and kind,
Line12: Or to thyself at least kind-hearted prove:
Line13: Make thee another self, for love of me,
Line14: That beauty still may live in thine or thee.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 11
Line1: As fast as thou shalt wane, so fast thou growest
Line2: In one of thine, from that which thou departest;
Line3: And that fresh blood which youngly thou bestowest
Line4: Thou mayst call thine when thou from youth convertest.
Line5: Herein lives wisdom, beauty and increase:
Line6: Without this, folly, age and cold decay:
Line7: If all were minded so, the times should cease
Line8: And threescore year would make the world away.
Line9: Let those whom Nature hath not made for store,
Line10: Harsh featureless and rude, barrenly perish:
Line11: Look, whom she best endow'd she gave the more;
Line12: Which bounteous gift thou shouldst in bounty cherish:
Line13: She carved thee for her seal, and meant thereby
Line14: Thou shouldst print more, not let that copy die.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 12
Line1: When I do count the clock that tells the time,
Line2: And see the brave day sunk in hideous night;
Line3: When I behold the violet past prime,
Line4: And sable curls all silver'd o'er with white;
Line5: When lofty trees I see barren of leaves
Line6: Which erst from heat did canopy the herd,
Line7: And summer's green all girded up in sheaves
Line8: Borne on the bier with white and bristly beard,
Line9: Then of thy beauty do I question make,
Line10: That thou among the wastes of time must go,
Line11: Since sweets and beauties do themselves forsake
Line12: And die as fast as they see others grow;
Line13: And nothing 'gainst Time's scythe can make defence
Line14: Save breed, to brave him when he takes thee hence.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 13
Line1: O, that you were yourself! but, love, you are
Line2: No longer yours than you yourself here live:
Line3: Against this coming end you should prepare,
Line4: And your sweet semblance to some other give.
Line5: So should that beauty which you hold in lease
Line6: Find no determination: then you were
Line7: Yourself again after yourself's decease,
Line8: When your sweet issue your sweet form should bear.
Line9: Who lets so fair a house fall to decay,
Line10: Which husbandry in honour might uphold
Line11: Against the stormy gusts of winter's day
Line12: And barren rage of death's eternal cold?
Line13: O, none but unthrifts! Dear my love, you know
Line14: You had a father: let your son say so.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 14
Line1: Not from the stars do I my judgment pluck;
Line2: And yet methinks I have astronomy,
Line3: But not to tell of good or evil luck,
Line4: Of plagues, of dearths, or seasons' quality;
Line5: Nor can I fortune to brief minutes tell,
Line6: Pointing to each his thunder, rain and wind,
Line7: Or say with princes if it shall go well,
Line8: By oft predict that I in heaven find:
Line9: But from thine eyes my knowledge I derive,
Line10: And, constant stars, in them I read such art
Line11: As truth and beauty shall together thrive,
Line12: If from thyself to store thou wouldst convert;
Line13: Or else of thee this I prognosticate:
Line14: Thy end is truth's and beauty's doom and date.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 15
Line1: When I consider every thing that grows
Line2: Holds in perfection but a little moment,
Line3: That this huge stage presenteth nought but shows
Line4: Whereon the stars in secret influence comment;
Line5: When I perceive that men as plants increase,
Line6: Cheered and cheque'd even by the self-same sky,
Line7: Vaunt in their youthful sap, at height decrease,
Line8: And wear their brave state out of memory;
Line9: Then the conceit of this inconstant stay
Line10: Sets you most rich in youth before my sight,
Line11: Where wasteful Time debateth with Decay,
Line12: To change your day of youth to sullied night;
Line13: And all in war with Time for love of you,
Line14: As he takes from you, I engraft you new.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 16
Line1: But wherefore do not you a mightier way
Line2: Make war upon this bloody tyrant, Time?
Line3: And fortify yourself in your decay
Line4: With means more blessed than my barren rhyme?
Line5: Now stand you on the top of happy hours,
Line6: And many maiden gardens yet unset
Line7: With virtuous wish would bear your living flowers,
Line8: Much liker than your painted counterfeit:
Line9: So should the lines of life that life repair,
Line10: Which this, Time's pencil, or my pupil pen,
Line11: Neither in inward worth nor outward fair,
Line12: Can make you live yourself in eyes of men.
Line13: To give away yourself keeps yourself still,
Line14: And you must live, drawn by your own sweet skill.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 17
Line1: Who will believe my verse in time to come,
Line2: If it were fill'd with your most high deserts?
Line3: Though yet, heaven knows, it is but as a tomb
Line4: Which hides your life and shows not half your parts.
Line5: If I could write the beauty of your eyes
Line6: And in fresh numbers number all your graces,
Line7: The age to come would say 'This poet lies:
Line8: Such heavenly touches ne'er touch'd earthly faces.'
Line9: So should my papers yellow'd with their age
Line10: Be scorn'd like old men of less truth than tongue,
Line11: And your true rights be term'd a poet's rage
Line12: And stretched metre of an antique song:
Line13: But were some child of yours alive that time,
Line14: You should live twice; in it and in my rhyme.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 18
Line1: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?
Line2: Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
Line3: Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,
Line4: And summer's lease hath all too short a date:
Line5: Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,
Line6: And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;
Line7: And every fair from fair sometime declines,
Line8: By chance or nature's changing course untrimm'd;
Line9: But thy eternal summer shall not fade
Line10: Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest;
Line11: Nor shall Death brag thou wander'st in his shade,
Line12: When in eternal lines to time thou growest:
Line13: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,
Line14: So long lives this and this gives life to thee.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 19
Line1: Devouring Time, blunt thou the lion's paws,
Line2: And make the earth devour her own sweet brood;
Line3: Pluck the keen teeth from the fierce tiger's jaws,
Line4: And burn the long-lived phoenix in her blood;
Line5: Make glad and sorry seasons as thou fleets,
Line6: And do whate'er thou wilt, swift-footed Time,
Line7: To the wide world and all her fading sweets;
Line8: But I forbid thee one most heinous crime:
Line9: O, carve not with thy hours my love's fair brow,
Line10: Nor draw no lines there with thine antique pen;
Line11: Him in thy course untainted do allow
Line12: For beauty's pattern to succeeding men.
Line13: Yet, do thy worst, old Time: despite thy wrong,
Line14: My love shall in my verse ever live young.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 20
Line1: A woman's face with Nature's own hand painted
Line2: Hast thou, the master-mistress of my passion;
Line3: A woman's gentle heart, but not acquainted
Line4: With shifting change, as is false women's fashion;
Line5: An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling,
Line6: Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth;
Line7: A man in hue, all 'hues' in his controlling,
Line8: Much steals men's eyes and women's souls amazeth.
Line9: And for a woman wert thou first created;
Line10: Till Nature, as she wrought thee, fell a-doting,
Line11: And by addition me of thee defeated,
Line12: By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.
Line13: But since she prick'd thee out for women's pleasure,
Line14: Mine be thy love and thy love's use their treasure.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 21
Line1: So is it not with me as with that Muse
Line2: Stirr'd by a painted beauty to his verse,
Line3: Who heaven itself for ornament doth use
Line4: And every fair with his fair doth rehearse
Line5: Making a couplement of proud compare,
Line6: With sun and moon, with earth and sea's rich gems,
Line7: With April's first-born flowers, and all things rare
Line8: That heaven's air in this huge rondure hems.
Line9: O' let me, true in love, but truly write,
Line10: And then believe me, my love is as fair
Line11: As any mother's child, though not so bright
Line12: As those gold candles fix'd in heaven's air:
Line13: Let them say more than like of hearsay well;
Line14: I will not praise that purpose not to sell.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 22
Line1: My glass shall not persuade me I am old,
Line2: So long as youth and thou are of one date;
Line3: But when in thee time's furrows I behold,
Line4: Then look I death my days should expiate.
Line5: For all that beauty that doth cover thee
Line6: Is but the seemly raiment of my heart,
Line7: Which in thy breast doth live, as thine in me:
Line8: How can I then be elder than thou art?
Line9: O, therefore, love, be of thyself so wary
Line10: As I, not for myself, but for thee will;
Line11: Bearing thy heart, which I will keep so chary
Line12: As tender nurse her babe from faring ill.
Line13: Presume not on thy heart when mine is slain;
Line14: Thou gavest me thine, not to give back again.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 23
Line1: As an unperfect actor on the stage
Line2: Who with his fear is put besides his part,
Line3: Or some fierce thing replete with too much rage,
Line4: Whose strength's abundance weakens his own heart.
Line5: So I, for fear of trust, forget to say
Line6: The perfect ceremony of love's rite,
Line7: And in mine own love's strength seem to decay,
Line8: O'ercharged with burden of mine own love's might.
Line9: O, let my books be then the eloquence
Line10: And dumb presagers of my speaking breast,
Line11: Who plead for love and look for recompense
Line12: More than that tongue that more hath more express'd.
Line13: O, learn to read what silent love hath writ:
Line14: To hear with eyes belongs to love's fine wit.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 24
Line1: Mine eye hath play'd the painter and hath stell'd
Line2: Thy beauty's form in table of my heart;
Line3: My body is the frame wherein 'tis held,
Line4: And perspective it is the painter's art.
Line5: For through the painter must you see his skill,
Line6: To find where your true image pictured lies;
Line7: Which in my bosom's shop is hanging still,
Line8: That hath his windows glazed with thine eyes.
Line9: Now see what good turns eyes for eyes have done:
Line10: Mine eyes have drawn thy shape, and thine for me
Line11: Are windows to my breast, where-through the sun
Line12: Delights to peep, to gaze therein on thee;
Line13: Yet eyes this cunning want to grace their art;
Line14: They draw but what they see, know not the heart.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 25
Line1: Let those who are in favour with their stars
Line2: Of public honour and proud titles boast,
Line3: Whilst I, whom fortune of such triumph bars,
Line4: Unlook'd for joy in that I honour most.
Line5: Great princes' favourites their fair leaves spread
Line6: But as the marigold at the sun's eye,
Line7: And in themselves their pride lies buried,
Line8: For at a frown they in their glory die.
Line9: The painful warrior famoused for fight,
Line10: After a thousand victories once foil'd,
Line11: Is from the book of honour razed quite,
Line12: And all the rest forgot for which he toil'd:
Line13: Then happy I, that love and am beloved
Line14: Where I may not remove nor be removed.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 26
Line1: Lord of my love, to whom in vassalage
Line2: Thy merit hath my duty strongly knit,
Line3: To thee I send this written embassage,
Line4: To witness duty, not to show my wit:
Line5: Duty so great, which wit so poor as mine
Line6: May make seem bare, in wanting words to show it,
Line7: But that I hope some good conceit of thine
Line8: In thy soul's thought, all naked, will bestow it;
Line9: Till whatsoever star that guides my moving
Line10: Points on me graciously with fair aspect
Line11: And puts apparel on my tatter'd loving,
Line12: To show me worthy of thy sweet respect:
Line13: Then may I dare to boast how I do love thee;
Line14: Till then not show my head where thou mayst prove me.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 27
Line1: Weary with toil, I haste me to my bed,
Line2: The dear repose for limbs with travel tired;
Line3: But then begins a journey in my head,
Line4: To work my mind, when body's work's expired:
Line5: For then my thoughts, from far where I abide,
Line6: Intend a zealous pilgrimage to thee,
Line7: And keep my drooping eyelids open wide,
Line8: Looking on darkness which the blind do see
Line9: Save that my soul's imaginary sight
Line10: Presents thy shadow to my sightless view,
Line11: Which, like a jewel hung in ghastly night,
Line12: Makes black night beauteous and her old face new.
Line13: Lo! thus, by day my limbs, by night my mind,
Line14: For thee and for myself no quiet find.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 28
Line1: How can I then return in happy plight,
Line2: That am debarr'd the benefit of rest?
Line3: When day's oppression is not eased by night,
Line4: But day by night, and night by day, oppress'd?
Line5: And each, though enemies to either's reign,
Line6: Do in consent shake hands to torture me;
Line7: The one by toil, the other to complain
Line8: How far I toil, still farther off from thee.
Line9: I tell the day, to please them thou art bright
Line10: And dost him grace when clouds do blot the heaven:
Line11: So flatter I the swart-complexion'd night,
Line12: When sparkling stars twire not thou gild'st the even.
Line13: But day doth daily draw my sorrows longer
Line14: And night doth nightly make grief's strength seem stronger.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 29
Line1: When, in disgrace with fortune and men's eyes,
Line2: I all alone beweep my outcast state
Line3: And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries
Line4: And look upon myself and curse my fate,
Line5: Wishing me like to one more rich in hope,
Line6: Featured like him, like him with friends possess'd,
Line7: Desiring this man's art and that man's scope,
Line8: With what I most enjoy contented least;
Line9: Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising,
Line10: Haply I think on thee, and then my state,
Line11: Like to the lark at break of day arising
Line12: From sullen earth, sings hymns at heaven's gate;
Line13: For thy sweet love remember'd such wealth brings
Line14: That then I scorn to change my state with kings.

Name: William Shakespeare - Sonnet 30
Line1: When to the sessions of sweet silent thought
Line2: I summon up remembrance of things past,
Line3: I sigh the lack of many a thing I sought,
Line4: And with old woes new wail my dear time's waste:
Line5: Then can I drown an eye, unused to flow,
Line6: For precious friends hid in death's dateless night,
Line7: And weep afresh love's long since cancell'd woe,
Line8: And moan the expense of many a vanish'd sight:
Line9: Then can I grieve at grievances foregone,
Line10: And heavily from woe to woe tell o'er
Line11: The sad account of fore-bemoaned moan,
Line12: Which I new pay as if not paid before.
Line13: But if the while I think on thee, dear friend,
Line14: All losses are restored and sorrows end.

Name: Pam Ayres – They Should Have Asked My Husband
Line1: You know, this world is complicated and imperfect and oppressed,
Line2: And it’s not hard to feel timid, apprehensive and depressed,
Line3: It seems that all around us, tides of questions ebb and flow,
Line4: And people want solutions, but they don’t know where to go.
Line5: Opinions abound but who is wrong and who is right?
Line6: People need a prophet, a diffuser of the light,
Line7: Someone they can turn to as the crises rage and swirl,
Line8: Someone with the remedy, the wisdom, the pearl…
Line9: * Well they should have asked my husband, he’s a man who likes his say,
Line10: With his thoughts on immigration, teenage mums, Theresa May,
Line11: The future of the monarchy, the latest Brexit shocks,
Line12: The wait for hip replacements, and the rubbish on the box.
Line13: Yes, they should have asked my husband, he can sort out any mess,
Line14: He can rejuvenate the railways, he can cure the NHS,
Line15: So any little niggle, anything you want to know,
Line16: Just run it past my husband, wind him up and let him go.
Line17: Congestion on the motorways, free holidays for thugs,
Line18: The damage to the ozone layer, refugees, drugs,
Line19: These may defeat the brain of any politician bloke,
Line20: But present it to my husband, he will solve it at a stroke.
Line21: He’ll clarify the situation, he will make it crystal clear,
Line22: You’ll feel the glazing of your eyeballs and the bending of your ear,
Line23: You may lose the will to live, you may feel your shoulders slump,
Line24: When he talks about the President, Mr. Donald Trump. *
Line25: Upon these areas he brings his intellect to shine,
Line26: In a great compelling voice that’s twice as loud as yours or mine,
Line27: I often wonder what it must be like to be so strong,
Line28: Infallible, articulate, self-confident and wrong.
Line29: When it comes to tolerance, he hasn’t got a lot,
Line30: Joy riders should be guillotined, and muggers should be shot,
Line31: The sound of his own voice becomes like music to his ears,
Line32: And he hasn’t got an inkling that he’s boring us to tears.
Line33: My friends don’t call so often, they have busy lives I know,
Line34: But it’s not every day you want to hear a windbag suck and blow,
Line35: Google? Safari? On them we never call,
Line36: Why bother with computers…when my husband knows it all.

Name: Pam Ayres – Down The Line
Line1: Down long-forgotten railway lines and over broken bridges
Line2: Came the young men,
Line3: From vanished stations with frilled eaves, past coal yards and sidings,
Line4: Over points switched by signalmen unseen,
Line5: They came from valleys green,
Line6: From blackened cities mean,
Line7: To battlefields obscene.
Line8: We ruined tracks that run below,
Line9: We saw them go, we saw them go,
Line10: Don’t let them hear the song of the track,
Line11: The clickety clack, the clackety clack,
Line12: They won’t come back.
Line13: Drawn like single threads to forge a cable,
Line14: From factories and shops, from farm and stable,
Line15: Football teams and banks and streets entire,
Line16: Through cuttings deep and scarred by summer fire,
Line17: Through tunnels dark, embankments steep, to face the threat,
Line18: To learn the ways of rifle and of bayonet
Line19: Hands which held the reins and steered the plough,
Line20: Must carry out more bloody service now,
Line21: Make hard the heart and subjugate the will,
Line22: To fire the bullet, stab and choke and kill,
Line23: For men, our country must more deeply delve,
Line24: Now some are fifty-six and some are twelve*
Line25: You mothers on windswept platforms, crippled by the gash of fear,
Line27: You aching sweetheart bent and crying for your young man,
Line28: Go home.
Line29: You have shared a last embrace.
Line30: Hold it tenderly, remember it, safeguard and cherish it,
Line31: For it must last a lifetime.
Line32: And pity the straight-backed fathers, who weep alone.
Line33: Over continents this was enacted,
Line34: Young men from their loving homes extracted,
Line35: Faces white and yellow, brown and black,
Line36: Believing that, one day, they would go back.
Line37: In haunted carriages I see them yet,
Line38: Khaki-clad, with kitbag, cigarette,
Line39: Through dim-lit panes they see me, far below,
Line40: I look into their eyes and watch them go.
Line41: They weren’t to know, as they travelled the lea,
Line42: The hideous scenes they were going to see
Line43: The flame, the gas cloud drifting, pale,
Line44: In Ypres, the Somme and Passchendaele.
Line45: To draw a last despairing breath,
Line46: Man and beast in a dismal death.
Line47: Carved names that crumble soft away,
Line48: In churches and on crosses grey,
Line49: At cenotaphs where poppies fall,
Line50: Embrace the life denied them all.

Name: Pam Ayres – Woodland Burial
Line1: Don’t lay me in some gloomy churchyard shaded by a wall,
Line2: Where the dust of ancient bones has spread a dryness over all,
Line3: Lay me in some leafy loam where, sheltered from the cold,
Line4: Little seeds investigate and tender leaves unfold.
Line5: There kindly and affectionately, plant a native tree,
Line6: To grow resplendent before God and hold some part of me.
Line7: The roots will not disturb me as they wend their peaceful way,
Line8: To build the fine and bountiful, from closure and decay.
Line9: To seek their small requirements so that when their work is done,
Line10: I’ll be tall and standing strongly in the beauty of the sun.

Name: Wilfred Owen – Dulce et Decorum Est
Line1: Bent double, like old beggars under sacks,
Line2: Knock-kneed, coughing like hags, we cursed through sludge,
Line3: Till on the haunting flares we turned our backs,
Line4: And towards our distant rest began to trudge.
Line5: Men marched asleep. Many had lost their boots,
Line6: But limped on, blood-shod. All went lame; all blind;
Line7: Drunk with fatigue; deaf even to the hoots
Line8: Of gas-shells dropping softly behind.
Line9: Gas! GAS! Quick, boys!—An ecstasy of fumbling
Line10: Fitting the clumsy helmets just in time,
Line11: But someone still was yelling out and stumbling
Line12: And flound’ring like a man in fire or lime.—
Line13: Dim through the misty panes and thick green light,
Line14: As under a green sea, I saw him drowning.
Line15: In all my dreams before my helpless sight,
Line16: He plunges at me, guttering, choking, drowning.
Line17: If in some smothering dreams, you too could pace
Line18: Behind the wagon that we flung him in,
Line19: And watch the white eyes writhing in his face,
Line20: His hanging face, like a devil’s sick of sin;
Line21: If you could hear, at every jolt, the blood
Line22: Come gargling from the froth-corrupted lungs,
Line23: Obscene as cancer, bitter as the cud
Line24: Of vile, incurable sores on innocent tongues,—
Line25: My friend, you would not tell with such high zest
Line26: To children ardent for some desperate glory,
Line27: The old Lie: Dulce et decorum est
Line28: Pro patria mori.

Name: Wilfred Owens – Exposure
Line1: Our brains ache, in the merciless iced east winds that knive us . . .
Line2: Wearied we keep awake because the night is silent . . .
Line3: Low drooping flares confuse our memory of the salient . . .
Line4: Worried by silence, sentries whisper, curious, nervous,
Line5: But nothing happens.
Line6: Watching, we hear the mad gusts tugging on the wire,
Line7: Like twitching agonies of men among its brambles.
Line8: Northward, incessantly, the flickering gunnery rumbles,
Line9: Far off, like a dull rumour of some other war.
Line10: What are we doing here?
Line11: The poignant misery of dawn begins to grow . . .
Line12: We only know war lasts, rain soaks, and clouds sag stormy.
Line13: Dawn massing in the east her melancholy army
Line14: Attacks once more in ranks on shivering ranks of grey,
Line15: But nothing happens.
Line16: Sudden successive flights of bullets streak the silence.
Line17: Less deadly than the air that shudders black with snow,
Line18: With sidelong flowing flakes that flock, pause, and renew,
Line19: We watch them wandering up and down the wind's nonchalance,
Line20: But nothing happens.
Line21: Pale flakes with fingering stealth come feeling for our faces—
Line22: We cringe in holes, back on forgotten dreams, and stare, snow-dazed,
Line23: Deep into grassier ditches. So we drowse, sun-dozed,
Line24: Littered with blossoms trickling where the blackbird fusses.
Line25: —Is it that we are dying?
Line26: Slowly our ghosts drag home: glimpsing the sunk fires, glozed
Line27: With crusted dark-red jewels; crickets jingle there;
Line28: For hours the innocent mice rejoice: the house is theirs;
Line29: Shutters and doors, all closed: on us the doors are closed,—
Line30: We turn back to our dying.
Line31: Since we believe not otherwise can kind fires burn;
Line32: Nor ever suns smile true on child, or field, or fruit.
Line33: For God's invincible spring our love is made afraid;
Line34: Therefore, not loath, we lie out here; therefore were born,
Line35: For love of God seems dying.
Line36: Tonight, this frost will fasten on this mud and us,
Line37: Shrivelling many hands, and puckering foreheads crisp.
Line38: The burying-party, picks and shovels in shaking grasp,
Line39: Pause over half-known faces. All their eyes are ice,
Line40: But nothing happens.

Name: Wilfred Owens – Insensitivity
Line1: I
Line2: Happy are men who yet before they are killed
Line3: Can let their veins run cold.
Line4: Whom no compassion fleers
Line5: Or makes their feet
Line6: Sore on the alleys cobbled with their brothers.
Line7: The front line withers.
Line8: But they are troops who fade, not flowers,
Line9: For poets’ tearful fooling:
Line10: Men, gaps for filling:
Line11: Losses, who might have fought
Line12: Longer; but no one bothers.
Line13: II
Line14: And some cease feeling
Line15: Even themselves or for themselves.
Line16: Dullness best solves
Line17: The tease and doubt of shelling,
Line18: And Chance’s strange arithmetic
Line19: Comes simpler than the reckoning of their shilling.
Line20: They keep no check on armies’ decimation.
Line21: III
Line22: Happy are these who lose imagination:
Line23: They have enough to carry with ammunition.
Line24: Their spirit drags no pack.
Line25: Their old wounds, save with cold, can not more ache.
Line27: Their eyes are rid
Line28: Of the hurt of the colour of blood for ever.
Line29: And terror’s first constriction over,
Line30: Their hearts remain small-drawn.
Line31: Their senses in some scorching cautery of battle
Line32: Now long since ironed,
Line33: Can laugh among the dying, unconcerned.
Line34: IV
Line35: Happy the soldier home, with not a notion
Line36: How somewhere, every dawn, some men attack,
Line37: And many sighs are drained.
Line38: Happy the lad whose mind was never trained:
Line39: His days are worth forgetting more than not.
Line40: He sings along the march
Line41: Which we march taciturn, because of dusk,
Line42: The long, forlorn, relentless trend
Line43: From larger day to huger night.
Line44: V
Line45: We wise, who with a thought besmirch
Line46: Blood over all our soul,
Line47: How should we see our task
Line48: But through his blunt and lashless eyes?
Line49: Alive, he is not vital overmuch;
Line50: Dying, not mortal overmuch;

Name: Wilfred Owens – Smile, Smile, Smile
Line1: Head to limp head, the sunk-eyed wounded scanned
Line2: Yesterday's Mail; the casualties (typed small)
Line3: And (large) Vast Booty from our Latest Haul.
Line4: Also, they read of Cheap Homes, not yet planned;
Line5: “For,” said the paper, “when this war is done
Line6: The men's first instinct will be making homes.
Line7: Meanwhile their foremost need is aerodromes,
Line8: It being certain war has just begun.
Line9: Peace would do wrong to our undying dead,—
Line10: The sons we offered might regret they died
Line11: If we got nothing lasting in their stead.
Line12: We must be solidly indemnified.
Line13: Though all be worthy Victory which all bought.
Line14: We rulers sitting in this ancient spot
Line15: Would wrong our very selves if we forgot
Line16: The greatest glory will be theirs who fought,
Line17: Who kept this nation in integrity.”
Line18: Nation?—The half-limbed readers did not chafe
Line19: But smiled at one another curiously
Line20: Like secret men who know their secret safe.
Line21: (This is the thing they know and never speak,
Line22: That England one by one had fled to France
Line23: Not many elsewhere now save under France).
Line24: Pictures of these broad smiles appear each week,
Line25: And people in whose voice real feeling rings
Line26: Say: How they smile! They're happy now, poor things.

Name: Margaret Atwood – Rat Song
Line1: When you hear me singing
Line2: you get the rifle down
Line3: and the flashlight, aiming for my brain,
Line4: but you always miss
Line5: and when you set out the poison
Line6: I piss on it
Line7: to warn the others.
Line8: You think: That one’s too clever,
Line9: she’s dangerous, because
Line10: I don’t stick around to be slaughtered
Line11: and you think I’m ugly too
