Line17: their flat or rounded butts, their rippling hair
Line18: or shiny domes, their fragile ankles,
Line19: their beautiful bones, all our atoms swimming, swimming
Line20: & making us visible & I shove off the wall,
Line21: reaching my arms out, embracing the whole
Line22: magic show, with ten more laps to go.

Name: M. Bartley Seigel – In The Bone-Cracking Cold
Line1: On this cross-quarter day, quick to temper and cool,
Line2: your long lashes startle me with their rime of hoarfrost,
Line3: and I am snared like a rabbit pulled into your gravity
Line4: by the run of our long love affair together. The seasons race past,
Line5: one following another, and the rising sap is soon to halo the maples again.
Line6: I will happily freeze in the bone-cracking cold, just to watch you
Line7: walk slowly through this sugarbush, rare as a sundog
Line8: incandescent in a fog of softly falling snow.

Name: Laura Secor – Bee Whisperer
Line1: For weeks we’ve seen some wild winds.
Line2: Today, I find my hives knocked over.
Line3: A season’s honey smeared in rivers
Line4: on the ground. I stand their domes again.
Line5: The bees are swarming in the trees and fighting
Line6: against the gale. I watch one entire colony
Line7: trapped by a whirlwind, carried out and up
Line8: across the Green. I run to follow and see them
Line9: swept over the river and caught in a maple grove.
Line10: Can anyone call bees?
Line11: Alone before the water’s edge,
Line12: in desperate worry for my colony,
Line13: not knowing what to do, I hold
Line14: my arms high, as if to block the wind,
Line15: and cry like swarming bees. I speak
Line16: about our apple blooms, promise
Line17: them acres of blossoms and honey mounds.
Line18: Your domes are upright, your babies waiting.
Line19: Suddenly, in one black cloud, they return
Line20: across the water, above my raised
Line21: head and waving arms, over the Green.
Line22: When I return, almost
Line23: horizontal against the raging winds,
Line24: I climb to my orchard, and find
Line25: the hives filling back

Name: Kai Coggin – Filling Spice Jars as Your Wife
Line1: It seems like all my poems
Line2: after this will be different,
Line3: they will hold a different weight
Line4: like how the weight of my heart
Line5: has shifted into indistinguishable float,
Line6: into lifting cloud,
Line7: into weightless flight tonight
Line8: as the rain gently falls
Line9: on the summer-heated tin roof,
Line10: the din of casual raindrops
Line11: and warm low lights glowing
Line12: and wind blowing through the house,
Line13: we have all our doors and windows open.
Line14: We have all our doors and windows open
Line15: and I am pouring spices into glass jars,
Line16: coriander cinnamon cumin ground sage
Line17: and it’s hard to describe this
Line18: moment in the confines of a page,
Line19: tiny hills of vibrant color
Line20: and intoxicating fragrance
Line21: and you hear the cadence
Line22: of my heart
Line23: from the kitchen
Line24: where you build the perfect fitting slip-in shelves
Line25: for our spices over the stove,
Line27: match my colors to yours,
Line28: I have all my doors and windows open to you.
Line29: I have all my doors and windows open to you
Line30: and you have come all the way inside,
Line31: sat down at the table of my deepest desires
Line32: and lit a fire to warm us both,
Line33: the wind blowing through the house,
Line34: the rain gently giving way
Line35: to turmeric sunrise
Line36: and you, darling,
Line37: you are my wife.
Line38: You are my wife
Line39: and it’s like I have been waiting
Line40: my whole life
Line41: to say those words,
Line42: and I feel held in a way
Line43: I have never felt before,
Line44: to look down at my fingers
Line46: and see the gold of my wedding band
Line47: glint and shine in the warm low light glow,
Line48: I am yours
Line49: and you are mine,
Line50: promised on Zoom in our garden

Name: Jacqueline Allen Trimble – The Language of Joy
Line1: Black woman joy is like this:
Line2: Mama said one day long before I was born
Line3: she was walking down the street,
Line4: foxes around her neck, their little heads
Line5: smiling up at her and out at the world
Line6: and she was wearing this suit she had saved up
Line7: a month’s paycheck for after it called to her so seductively
Line8: from the window of this boutique. And that suit
Line9: was wearing her, keeping all its promises
Line10: in all the right places. Indigo. Matching gloves.
Line11: Suede shoes dippity-do-dahed in blue.
Line12: With tassels! Honey gold. And, Lord, a hat
Line13: with plume de peacock, a conductor’s baton that bounced
Line14: to hip rhythm. She looked so fine she thought
Line15: Louis Armstrong might pop up out of those movies
Line16: she saw as a child, wipe his forehead and sing
Line17: ba da be bop oh do de doe de doe doe.
Line18: And he did. Mama did not sing but she was skiddly-doing that day,
Line19: and the foxes grinned, and she grinned
Line20: and she was the star of her own Hollywood musical
Line21: here with Satchmo who had called Ella over and now they were all
Line22: singing and dancing like a free people up Dexter Avenue,
Line23: and don’t think they didn’t know they were walking in the footsteps
Line24: of slaves and over auction sites and past where old Wallace
Line25: had held onto segregation like a life raft, but this
Line26: was not that day. This day was for foxes and hip rhythm
Line27: and musical perfection and folks on the street joining in the celebration
Line28: of breath and holiness. And they did too. In color-coordinated ensembles,
Line29: they kicked and turned and grinned and shouted like church
Line30: or football game, whatever their religious preference. The air
Line31: vibrated with music, arms, legs, and years of unrequited
Line32: sunshine. Somebody did a flip up Dexter Avenue.
Line33: It must have been a Nicholas Brother in a featured performance,
Line34: and Mama was Miss-Lena-Horne-Dorothy-Dandridge
Line35: high-stepping up the real estate, ready for her close-up.
Line36: That’s when Mama felt this little tickle. She thought
Line37: it might be pent-up joy, until a mouse squirmed out
Line38: from underneath that fine collar, over that fabulous fur,
Line39: jumped off her shoulder and ran down the street.
Line40: Left my mama standing there on Dexter Avenue in her blue
Line41: suit and dead foxes. And what did Mama do?
Line42: Everybody looking at her, robbed by embarrassment?
Line43: She said, “It be like that sometimes,” then she and Satchmo,
Line44: Ella, and the whole crew jammed their way home.

Name: Voice Porter – A Poem for Indigo
Line1: For nothing more than the Love of my people
Line2: I fight
Line3: staying my path
Line4: honoring the ancestors
Line5: dragging the children to freedom with the passion of the Christ
Line6: because even as a child You freed my mind
Line7: and I Love Your imperfections
Line8: the way You colored outside the lines
Line9: though Your artwork didn’t win any prizes
Line10: as an adult Your heart’s work saves lives
Line11: and touches souls unknown even to You
Line12: and it pleases God to see You do what You do
Line13: because the truth isn’t always what’s said
Line14: but in the hand’s work
Line15: and no matter what comes and goes
Line16: He will be edified through man’s work
Line17: and You
Line18: You’ve done a lion’s share
Line19: tending the fields and feeding His sheep until Your hands hurt
Line20: what more can we ask for?
Line21: from the time they leave it in the morning
Line22: ’til after the Sun cries
Line23: and Your knees hit the floor
Line24: and I beseech thee
Line25: take a few moments of time to teach these others
Line26: who only pretend and fall short
Line27: because their work wasn’t from the heart
Line28: they were monetarily motivated from the start
Line29: but from the moment that I opened my eyes
Line30: there You were right where You’ve always been
Line31: with me looking for the truth so hard
Line32: making it hard to find it
Line33: but here You stand
Line34: and I’ll believe in You from now until judgment call
Line35: I pray that I’ll have from now until then to figure out a title to give You
Line36: because You are more than a friend
Line37: I’m prepared to be the same to You from now until the end
Line38: perpetually moving through life cycles until my life cycle ends
Line39: these might be my last days
Line40: this poem might be my last peace
Line41: so I’ve got to speak my peace
Line42: because this piece could very well be my eulogy
Line43: in the back of my mind thoughts of You cascade down like waterfalls
Line44: as water falls against glass
Line46: becomes streams on my cheeks
Line47: and puddles in my palms
Line48: for the celestial being You are
Line49: I give alms to Him
Line50: and pray that I receive ilm forthright

Name: Jacqueline Allen Trimble – A Woman Cohabitates with Three Men
Line1: Not glamorous like it sounds. Two duplicates and the original.
Line2: They roar and snort. Beat their chests. Scratch. Always loud,
Line3: half-naked. Drop their garments like bread crumbs. Lose things.
Line4: Scratch some more. Lose everything beneath and behind. Inexplicable spaces
Line5: lodge their plunder: tablets, homework, tax returns, a chicken bone
Line6: altar. That yellow shoe I will have to find later,
Line7: my uterus translated into divining rod. Bodies as battering rams
Line8: of sound. Mismatched chromosomes. Weapons of chaos. Truncheons. Trebuchets. Terrors.
Line9: And yet, I love them. My sweet boys. Feckless warriors—
Line10: Destroyers of kitchens. Enemies of my solitude. You have been
Line11: too long from conquering. The wilderness calls your names, and
Line12: I say go. Take up your armor, gloves, and boots.
Line13: Sharpen your swing blade, hatchet, and rake. Cover your loins.
Line14: Go forth, my darlings, into the feral backyard and slay.

Name: Annik Adey-Babinski – Swimming Pool 2020
Line1: When my baby was born
Line2: she was laid on my belly.
Line3: Her cord was too short to bring her higher.
Line4: She lifted her head
Line5: and looked around.
Line6: When they could
Line7: my placenta was brought up to me and
Line8: placed in the crook of my arm.
Line9: Then my baby came up to my breast.
Line10: Still slow and watery
Line11: she watched us
Line12: name her call her ours
Line13: stitch me up cut our cord
Line14: when it went white.
Line15: She never cried.
Line16: When I bring her in the water now
Line17: she watches silently
Line18: as we take on
Line19: a familiar weightlessness.
Line20: My hair floats out around us.
Line21: I hold her in my shadow.
Line22: I am her moon.
Line23: She watches the empty deck.
Line24: The pool vacuum circles us like a planet.
Line25: She holds her hand out
Line26: and pets the hose as it passes.

Name: Nyah Hardmoon – Cocoon
Line1: My nana be born caterpillar, but she didn’t stay that way.
Line2: How silly it is to live a beginning so different from the end.
Line3: Scrunched up on ground, not knowing you will soon be cousins with the sky.
Line4: My nana be pretty wings and all.
Line5: Fluttering on by one stroke at a time. She be
Line6: Free. Tempting the fate of gravity.
Line7: Flying high, flying neat.
Line8: She laughs and music is born, wings beating to the beat.
Line9: When she come around the air grows sweet with rhythm and blues.
Line10: She be queen bee and B.B. her king.
Line11: Line dancing through the clouds,
Line12: my nana be butterflying, in every sense of the word.
Line13: Sees the world as her canvas and uses her wings to paint life onto every surface she kisses,
Line14: And man do them wings glisten.
Line15: Something straight out of a Maxwell song.
Line16: Too pretty to remain on ground so sky is where she be
Line17: And man do she be flyin’.
Line18: When you’ve lived how she lived on the other end
Line19: You learn to never let go of freedom’s hand. Never forget its taste.
Line20: She flies as if the moment she stops she will plummet to ground again.
Line21: My nana be caterpillar at heart.
Line22: Not knowing why she was gifted such beautiful rebirth
Line23: But knowing that it is here now and here it will stay, at least she prays.
Line24: My nana be born hopeless
Line25: But she didn’t stay that way.

Name: Casey Thayer – Guards at the Taj
Line1: Nearly asleep again in my arms after hunger
Line2: woke her in the middle of the night,
Line3: my daughter discovers her hands and, dazed,
Line4: studies the small movements they can make,
Line5: amazed to find they’re hers to manipulate.
Line6: Years ago, on a hot afternoon in Agra,
Line7: our guide recited the same tired anecdotes
Line8: as we walked the crowded streets
Line9: toward the mausoleum: that guards at the Taj
Line10: were forbidden to look in during the building,
Line11: that some went mad waiting for years
Line12: to glimpse the dome after the barrier walls
Line13: were torn down. It might be a myth—
Line14: how Shah Jahan ordered his soldiers
Line15: to cut off the hands of the craftsmen
Line16: to keep them from repeating the wonder—
Line17: but even myths can trigger belief.
Line18: How long would it have taken them—
Line19: the guards—to grow numb to its beauty?
Line20: Our guide had visited too often to find
Line21: any revelations and hung back in the shade
Line22: of a banyan as we approached the tomb.
Line23: I remember the buzz in the queue, gasps
Line24: of visitors as they passed through the gate,
Line25: language failing the deeper in we walked.
Line26: Now, a clear night, in the glow of the moon,
Line27: my daughter’s attention to the routine magic
Line28: of our bodies, to the draw of color
Line29: and shape. My daughter, a conduit
Line30: through which I notice, again, my hands
Line31: and what they’re holding, the massive
Line32: towers we’ve built outside our windows,
Line33: and a night train—empty at this hour,
Line34: or taking some lone soul home—
Line35: flashing in the gap between two high-rises.

Name: Vievee Francis – Ars Poetica
Line1: I keep rifles in the front closet.
Line2: Trespassing can be a glance.
Line3: A good shot,
Line4: I practice with bottles, bull's eyes.
Line5: I cross the line where the fence breaks,
Line6: where the wood falls in unintended directions,
Line7: and prepare an offensive
Line8: before any repair.
Line9: I know the value of my property.
Line10: Ungloved, I place the barbed wire.

Name: Vievee Francis – Still Life with Summer Sausage, A Blade, and No Blood
Line1: I remember, we walked (we didn't walk)
Line2: from the farmhouse to the store in Palestine
Line3: (we drove the truck, got out, went in).
Line4: The storefronts hadn't changed since
Line5: my father was a child. He grabbed saltines from the bin
Line6: (he brought a box) and he bought some sausage.
Line7: We walked (yes, then we walked) around town
Line8: as we ate (he shared). He gave me some summer
Line9: sausage, cut with his pocket knife. I pulled the pieces
Line10: from the point of the blade. I knew (knew)
Line11: nothing would happen (though he was silent)
Line12: to alter this memory. We were together
Line13: in Texas and we ate and walked in silence
Line14: and it felt like smiling, like skipping, like saying,
Line15: "Daddy" and him not minding, not minding at all.

Name: April Halprin Wayland – Spring Break
Line1: The best clouds in the business
Line2: are right above me
Line3: right now.
Line4: We’re riding in this teal convertible
Line5: those clouds just dozing
Line6: in about forty-nine different shapes
Line7: white as clean paper,
Line8: their edges like feathers against the blue sky,
Line9: blue as Dad’s eyes.
Line10: Dad drives, my sister’s in front
Line11: I lay my head on Mom’s lap in the back.
Line12: I lay my head on her lap as he drives
Line13: this teal convertible that we rented special
Line14: just for these four days in Albuquerque.
Line15: In it, we are open to the whole world
Line16: to the whole sky
Line17: and I know right now
Line18: I can see
Line19: that these are
Line20: the best clouds in the business.

Name: Linda Sue Park – Red-Crowed Crane
Line1: Rare cranes have flourished in the world’s unlikeliest sanctuary, the heavily mined demilitarized zone between North and South Korea.
Line2: —Smithsonian Magazine
Line3: curve and swoosh
Line4: of wondrous white
Line5: brushstroked black
Line6: the throat and wings
Line7: modest cap of scarlet
Line8: stretch and flap
Line9: a regal span
Line10: dance romance
Line11: on chopstick legs
Line12: elegant and awkward
Line13: nest and stalk
Line14: between the mines
Line15: screech and whoop
Line16: past endless loops
Line17: of  shining razor wire

Name: Tina Boyer Brown – School—12:15
Line1: Imagine the lunchroom,
Line2: crowded and wary—
Line3: seating charts a welcome apprehension.
Line4: Loose-leaf
Line5: papers spiraled from
Line6: ballpoint-scratched notebook covers
Line7: until the last hour,
Line8: when a teacher
Line9: sighed and sighed.
Line10: Today, we close our backpacks,
Line11: but minutes
Line12: come quick and quit
Line13: the ease of dawn.

Name: Michael Rosen – Once
Line1: Once there was a boy who
Line2: wanted to be beautiful
Line3: and a girl who
Line4: wanted to be strong.
Line5: The boy was worried
Line6: that he wasn’t beautiful enough.
Line7: The girl was worried
Line8: that she wasn’t strong enough.
Line9: One day they went out to seek
Line10: their fortunes.
Line11: But there was nothing.
Line12: There was nowhere for them to go
Line13: Nothing for them to see
Line14: No one for them to meet.
Line15: There was no story for them
Line16: to be in.

Line19: but they hadn’t
Line20: because there wasn’t anywhere
Line21: for them to meet.

Name: Michael Rosen – Down Behind the Dustbin
Line1: Down behind the dustbin
Line2: I met a dog called Ted.
Line3: ‘Leave me alone,’ he says,
Line4: ‘I’m just going to bed.’
Line5: Down behind the dustbin
Line6: I met a dog called Roger.

Line9: Down behind the dustbin
Line10: I met a dog called Sue.

Name: Michael Rosen – Chocolate Cake
Line1: I love chocolate cake.
Line2: And when I was a boy
Line3: I loved it even more.
Line4: Sometimes we used to have it for tea
Line5: and Mum used to say,
Line6: 'If there's any left over
Line7: you can have it to take to school
Line8: tomorrow to have at playtime.'
Line9: And the next day I would take it to school
Line10: wrapped up in tin foil
Line11: open it up at playtime
Line12: and sit in the corner of the playground
Line13: eating it,
Line14: you know how the icing on top
Line15: is all shiny and it cracks as you
Line16: bite into it,
Line17: and there's that other kind of icing in
Line18: the middle
Line19: and it sticks to your hands and you
Line20: can lick your fingers
Line21: and lick your lips
Line22: oh it's lovely.
Line23: yeah.
Line24: Anyway,
Line25: once we had this chocolate cake for tea
Line26: and later I went to bed
Line27: but while I was in bed
Line28: I found myself waking up
Line29: licking my lips
Line30: and smiling.
Line31: I woke up proper.
Line32: 'The chocolate cake.'
Line33: It was the first thing
Line34: 1 thought of.
Line35: I could almost see it
Line36: so I thought,
Line37: what if I go downstairs
Line38: and have a little nibble, yeah?
Line39: It was all dark
Line40: everyone was in bed
Line41: so it must have been really late
Line42: but I got out of bed,
Line43: crept out of the door
Line44: there's always a creaky floorboard, isn't there?
Line46: careful not to tread on bits of broken toys
Line47: or bits of Lego
Line48: you know what it's like treading on Lego
Line49: with your bare feet,
Line50: yowwww

Line3: from Clapham Common

Name: Langston Hughes – Let America be America Again
Line1: Let America be America again.
Line2: Let it be the dream it used to be.
Line3: Let it be the pioneer on the plain
Line4: Seeking a home where he himself is free.
Line5: (America never was America to me.)
Line6: Let America be the dream the dreamers dreamed—
Line7: Let it be that great strong land of love
Line8: Where never kings connive nor tyrants scheme
Line9: That any man be crushed by one above.
Line10: (It never was America to me.)
Line11: O, let my land be a land where Liberty
Line12: Is crowned with no false patriotic wreath,
Line13: But opportunity is real, and life is free,
Line14: Equality is in the air we breathe.
Line15: (There's never been equality for me,
Line16: Nor freedom in this "homeland of the free.")
Line17: Say, who are you that mumbles in the dark?
Line18: And who are you that draws your veil across the stars?
Line19: I am the poor white, fooled and pushed apart,
Line20: I am the Negro bearing slavery's scars.
Line21: I am the red man driven from the land,
Line22: I am the immigrant clutching the hope I seek—
Line23: And finding only the same old stupid plan
Line24: Of dog eat dog, of mighty crush the weak.
Line25: I am the young man, full of strength and hope,
Line26: Tangled in that ancient endless chain
Line27: Of profit, power, gain, of grab the land!
Line28: Of grab the gold! Of grab the ways of satisfying need!
Line29: Of work the men! Of take the pay!
Line30: Of owning everything for one's own greed!
Line31: I am the farmer, bondsman to the soil.
Line32: I am the worker sold to the machine.
Line33: I am the Negro, servant to you all.
Line34: I am the people, humble, hungry, mean—
Line35: Hungry yet today despite the dream.
Line36: Beaten yet today—O, Pioneers!
Line37: I am the man who never got ahead,
Line38: The poorest worker bartered through the years.
Line39: Yet I'm the one who dreamt our basic dream
Line40: In the Old World while still a serf of kings,
Line41: Who dreamt a dream so strong, so brave, so true,
Line42: That even yet its mighty daring sings
Line43: In every brick and stone, in every furrow turned
Line44: That's made America the land it has become.
Line45: O, I'm the man who sailed those early seas
Line46: In search of what I meant to be my home—
Line47: For I'm the one who left dark Ireland's shore,
Line48: And Poland's plain, and England's grassy lea,
Line49: And torn from Black Africa's strand I came
Line50: To build a "homeland of the free."

Name: Langston Hughes – Flatted Fifths
Line1: Little cullud boys with beards
Line2: re-bop be-bop mop and stop.
Line3: Little cullud boys with fears,
Line4: frantic, kick their CC years
Line5: into flatted fifths and flatter beers
Line6: that at a sudden change become
Line7: sparkling Oriental wines
Line8: rich and strange
Line9: silken bathrobes with gold twines
Line10: and Heilbroner, Crawford,
Line11: Nat-undreamed-of Lewis combines
Line12: in silver thread and diamond notes
Line13: on trade-marks inside
Line14: Howard coats.
Line15: Little cullud boys in berets
Line16: oop pop-a-da
Line17: horse a fantasy of days
Line18: ool ya koo
Line19: and dig all plays.

Name: Langston Hughes – Dreams

Line3: Life is a broken-winged bird
Line4: That cannot fly.
Line5: Hold fast to dreams
Line6: For when dreams go
Line7: Life is a barren field
Line8: Frozen with snow.

Name: Langston Hughes – Dream Boogie: Variation
Line1: Tinkling treble,

Name: Langston Hughes – Cross
Line1: My old man’s a white old man

Name: Langston Hughes – Snail

Line9: Mystery.

Name: Langston Hughes – Motto

Name: Langston Hughes – If-ing

Name: Anne Stevenson – To My Daughter In A Red Coat
Line1: Late October. It is afternoon.
Line2: My daughter and I walk through the leaf-strewn
Line3: Corridors of the park
Line4: In the light and the dark
Line5: Of the elms' thin arches.
Line6: Around us brown leaves fall and spread.
Line7: Small winds stir the minor dead.
Line8: Dust powders the air.
Line9: Those shrivelled women stare.
Line10: At us from their cold benches.
Line11: Child, your mittens tug your sleeves.
Line12: They lick your drumming feet, the leaves.
Line13: You come so fast, so fast.
Line14: You violate the past,
Line15: My daughter, as your coat dances.

Name: Emmanuel Xavier – Old Pro
Line1: I wanted to be a poet. I hustled my way
Line2: into the literary scene much like I had at the piers.
Line3: They watched me dare to speak my truth. They said,
Line4: “Good for you! Talking openly about your
Line5: experiences as a queer poet of color and being
Line6: sex positive.” They felt what I was doing wasn’t
Line7: poetry. I heard them say I was only popular
Line8: because I was a whore. I listened to them.
Line9: Gave them permission to use me. Let them
Line10: take pictures of me in my underwear to
Line11: promote readings. They mispronounced
Line12: my name and spelled it incorrectly. And expected
Line13: me to show up and perform for them.
Line14: Bring in the crowd. They slut-shamed me into
Line15: a cage in a small dark room that smelled like piss.
Line16: I wanted to be a poet. I wanted to escape my past
Line17: as a prostitute. Maya Angelou had been a sex worker
Line18: and became a poet. In bed I wrote poems. I cuddled
Line19: with cats. I thought what I was sharing was
Line20: important. I thought what I was doing was significant.
Line21: I thought poetry was meant for everyone. I made
Line22: mistakes in my rebellion. I was almost killed.
Line23: I believed Audre Lorde that my silence would
Line24: not protect me. I wrote to be more like Assotto
Line25: Saint. I was inspired by homophobic
Line26: contemporaries who hated me. I did not attend
Line27: their workshops or teach alongside them
Line28: in schools. I watched them become famous.
Line29: I watched a new generation of poets pretend
Line30: they did everything first. I watched them
Line31: innovate and influence as I became invisible.
Line32: Again. I used my first and middle name to be
Line33: remembered. My last name belonged
Line34: to a deadbeat dad. I tried to write about what I
Line35: knew at a time when they did not care about Houses
Line36: or underground communities. DEI was not an
Line37: acronym for diversity, equity, and inclusion.
Line38: More like disenfranchise, exclude, and ignore.
Line39: I read in front of large audiences and by myself
Line40: to a phone camera. I thought I would reach
Line41: my father this way someday. I thought I would meet
Line42: the love of my life this way someday. Instead, we met
Line43: the old school way—at a seedy bar. After marching
Line44: against racism. He jokingly calls me “A-Manuel.”
Line45: He can recite the lines of my better-known poems.
Line46: He loves to tell stories. He knows there is only one
Line47: m in my first name. We both learned the truth
Line48: about my father. Now know his name. Where he
Line49: lives in Florida. He lets me discuss my past. He lets
Line50: me find the time to read and write. He is my literary award.

Name: Timothy Liu – Love Poem: Cavafy
Line1: Coming back
Line2: from the ski trip
Line3: in the back of a van,
Line4: it had gotten dark
Line5: enough for
Line6: the steady hum
Line7: of the engine
Line8: to lull us all
Line9: into a deep sleep—
Line10: my best friend
Line11: and I having
Line12: the backseat
Line13: all to ourselves.
Line14: Have you ever felt
Line15: your body starting
Line16: to lean toward
Line17: its truest
Line18: intentions—head
Line19: hoping hard
Line20: for a soft landing
Line21: on your buddy’s
Line22: dozing shoulders?—
Line23: a journey in inches
Line24: that took me years.

Name: Spencer Reece – Poeta en Nueva York
Line1: Lorca, 5 am and I am slathered in Spain:
Line2: cologne, exhaust, coffee, chorizo, the tang
Line3: of an old body that needs to be washed.
Line4: I’m on the top floor. 18 West 10th Street.
Line5: The Emma Lazarus house: “Send these,
Line6: the homeless, tempest-tost to me,
Line7: I lift my lamp beside the golden door!”
Line8: I hold my passport, covered in stamps.
Line9: I’ve double-checked it twice. The moon
Line10: in the window is crinkled up like Kleenex.
Line11: Now more light—light, here and here,
Line12: then there and there—light, light, light,
Line13: light—on the Regency desk a framed photo
Line14: of Andrew and John, married at Althorp.
Line15: Lorca, two men I love who love each other—
Line16: what a privilege to witness a spoken love!
Line17: My suitcase open on the floor, wishes packed
Line18: like in the Declaration of Independence.
Line19: The doctors urged me to come: a stroke,
Line20: a brain bleed, my mother’s occipital lobe.
Line21: una de las dos españas ha de helarte el corazón
Line22: Lorca, the sun kisses the city like a Spaniard.
Line23: Kiss kiss! I see Wall Street over the balustrade,
Line24: where once there were two towers, now
Line25: one—everything eventually subtracts.
Line26: Frank Doyle, my classmate, died in that.
Line27: Frank knew what I now know, when you
Line28: become a ghost in one world you become
Line29: a guest in another. Leaves fall outside.
Line30: Lorca, I am not ready to speak English—
Line31: chopped syllables, the tongue less languid.
Line32: My mind still preoccupied with the tempo
Line33: of Spain, not ready to change languages
Line34: like clothes. Spain has no Puritanical itches.
Line35: Lorca, on the gay nude beach in Sitges
Line36: the empty church stuck out from the shore
Line37: like a giant body part. I laid my body down
Line38: with the rest and felt free as the sea crashed
Line39: against us. I work in a conservative church
Line40: in the gay district, the church loves me,
Line41: the district loves me, the two do not meet,
Line42: always I must deliberate over which is which.
Line43: lorca eran todos
Line44: Lorca, what time, what time is it?
Line45: My mother’s brain bleeds. Once we mounted
Line46: a festival in Madrid, and you were there.
Line47: Your niece helped me; her eyes so brown
Line48: they were black. Showed me your single bed,
Line49: how your body had molded the mattress.
Line50: The body. And the absence of the body.

Name: Lillian-Yvonne Bertram – Lineage Anagrams I
Line1: Pinned to the orchard, the alge-
Line2: bra of unfolded diapers drying on the line
Line3: and skyward brays a plane. Slack bees lean
Line4: and a car cars down the street, the cloth angle
Line5: of the small’s small day’s shadows lie
Line6: above the late-brown grass in the lee
Line7: season, and finally their children’s children lean
Line8: forward on archimedal chins and our genial
Line9: kin are sunned upon. Lawn mower, maybe drill, a nag
Line10: some ways down the summer block. Glean
Line11: the baby’s cry, the seas inside slackwater lag
Line12: in this place where I was a child, am a child, now the age
Line13: of the child’s parents. Another child nows in the gene
Line14: and its small shape in the bathwater is the el in angel.
Line15: Outside on the grass I listen up, and hear in the window’s leg
Line16: the child, a mother singing to the child, and an age.

Name: Jamila Woods – on naming yourself
Line1: i caught my breath & called that life

Line6: of orange peels and doorways
Line7: i arrive at a space that no longer needs

Line9: of telling each other the truth
Line10: where they suck the bones of the alphabet
Line11: over a floor of rubble & gravel & ashes

Line16: from ourselves

Name: Maya Angelou – On the Pulse of Morning
Line1: A Rock, A River, A Tree
Line2: Hosts to species long since departed,
Line3: Marked the mastodon,
Line4: The dinosaur, who left dried tokens
Line5: Of their sojourn here
Line6: On our planet floor,
Line7: Any broad alarm of their hastening doom
Line8: Is lost in the gloom of dust and ages.
Line9: But today, the Rock cries out to us, clearly, forcefully,
Line10: Come, you may stand upon my
Line11: Back and face your distant destiny,
Line12: But seek no haven in my shadow,
Line13: I will give you no hiding place down here.
Line14: You, created only a little lower than
Line15: The angels, have crouched too long in
Line16: The bruising darkness
Line17: Have lain too long
Line18: Facedown in ignorance,
Line19: Your mouths spilling words
Line20: Armed for slaughter.
Line21: The Rock cries out to us today,
Line22: You may stand upon me,
Line23: But do not hide your face.

Name: Maya Angelou – Caged Bird
Line1: A free bird leaps
Line2: on the back of the wind
Line3: and floats downstream
Line4: till the current ends
Line5: and dips his wing
Line6: in the orange sun rays
Line7: and dares to claim the sky.
Line8: But a bird that stalks
Line9: down his narrow cage
Line10: can seldom see through
Line11: his bars of rage
Line12: his wings are clipped and
Line13: his feet are tied
Line14: so he opens his throat to sing.
Line15: The caged bird sings
Line16: with a fearful trill
Line17: of things unknown
Line18: but longed for still
Line19: and his tune is heard
Line20: on the distant hill
Line21: for the caged bird
Line22: sings of freedom.
Line23: The free bird thinks of another breeze
Line24: and the trade winds soft through the sighing trees
Line25: and the fat worms waiting on a dawn bright lawn
Line26: and he names the sky his own.
Line27: But a caged bird stands on the grave of dreams
Line28: his shadow shouts on a nightmare scream
Line29: his wings are clipped and his feet are tied
Line30: so he opens his throat to sing.
Line31: The caged bird sings
Line32: with a fearful trill
Line33: of things unknown
Line34: but longed for still
Line35: and his tune is heard
Line36: on the distant hill
Line37: for the caged bird
Line38: sings of freedom.

Name: Maya Angelou – A Plagued Journey
Line1: There is no warning rattle at the door
Line2: nor heavy feet to stomp the foyer boards.
Line3: Safe in the dark prison, I know that
Line4: light slides over
Line5: the fingered work of a toothless
Line6: woman in Pakistan.
Line7: Happy prints of
Line8: an invisible time are illumined.
Line9: My mouth agape
Line10: rejects the solid air and
Line11: lungs hold. The invader takes
Line12: direction and
Line13: seeps through the plaster walls.
Line14: It is at my chamber, entering
Line15: the keyhole, pushing
Line16: through the padding of the door.
Line17: I cannot scream. A bone
Line18: of fear clogs my throat.
Line19: It is upon me. It is
Line20: sunrise, with Hope
Line21: its arrogant rider.
Line22: My mind, formerly quiescent
Line23: in its snug encasement, is strained
Line24: to look upon their rapturous visages,
Line25: to let them enter even into me.
Line27: outside myself to
Line28: mount the light and ride joined with Hope.
Line29: Through all the bright hours
Line30: I cling to expectation, until
Line31: darkness comes to reclaim me
Line32: as its own. Hope fades, day is gone
Line33: into its irredeemable place
Line34: and I am thrown back into the familiar
Line35: bonds of disconsolation.
Line36: Gloom crawls around
Line37: lapping lasciviously
Line38: between my toes, at my ankles,
Line39: and it sucks the strands of my
Line40: hair. It forgives my heady
Line41: fling with Hope. I am
Line42: joined again into its
Line43: greedy arms.

Name: Maya Angelou – California Prodigal
Line1: The eye follows, the land
Line2: Slips upward, creases down, forms
Line3: The gentle buttocks of a young
Line4: Giant. In the nestle,
Line5: Old adobe bricks, washed of
Line6: Whiteness, paled to umber,
Line7: Await another century.
Line8: Star Jasmine and old vines
Line9: Lay claim upon the ghosted land,
Line10: Then quiet pools whisper
Line11: Private childhood secrets.
Line12: Flush on inner cottage walls
Line13: Antiquitous faces,
Line14: Used to the gelid breath
Line15: Of old manors, glare disdainfully
Line16: Over breached time.
Line17: Around and through these
Line18: Cold phantasmatalities,
Line19: He walks, insisting
Line20: To the languid air,
Line21: Activity, music,
Line22: A generosity of graces.
Line23: His lupin fields spurn old
Line24: Deceit and agile poppies dance
Line25: In golden riot.   Each day is
Line27: Under the gaze of his exquisite
Line28: Sires, frozen in the famed paint
Line29: Of dead masters. Audacious
Line30: Sunlight casts defiance
Line31: At their feet.

Name: Maya Angelou – Kin
Line1: We were entwined in red rings
Line2: Of blood and loneliness before
Line3: The first snows fell
Line4: Before muddy rivers seeded clouds
Line5: Above a virgin forest, and
Line6: Men ran naked, blue and black
Line7: Skinned into the warm embraces
Line8: Of Sheba, Eve and Lilith.
Line9: I was your sister.
Line10: You left me to force strangers
Line11: Into brother molds, exacting
Line12: Taxations they never
Line13: Owed or could ever pay.
Line14: You fought to die, thinking
Line15: In destruction lies the seed
Line16: Of birth. You may be right.
Line17: I will remember silent walks in
Line18: Southern woods and long talks
Line19: In low voices
Line20: Shielding meaning from the big ears
Line21: Of overcurious adults.
Line22: You may be right.
Line23: Your slow return from
Line24: Regions of terror and bloody
Line25: Screams, races my heart.
Line27: Of children and see fireflies
Line28: Bursting tiny explosions in
Line29: An Arkansas twilight.

Name: Dante Alighieri – VII. Sonnet
Line1: Upon a day, came Sorrow in to me,
Line2: Saying, "I’ve come to stay with thee a while;"
Line3: And I perceived that she had usher'd Bile
Line4: And Pain into my house for company.
Line5: Wherefore I said, "Go forth—away with thee!"
Line6: But like a Greek she answer'd, full of guile,
Line7: And went on arguing in an easy style.
Line8: Then, looking, I saw Love come silently,
Line9: Habited in black raiment, smooth and new,
Line10: Having a black hat set upon his hair;
Line11: And certainly the tears he shed were true.
Line12: So that I ask'd, "What ails thee, trifler?"
Line13: Answering he said: "A grief to be gone through;
Line14: For our own lady’s dying, brother dear."

Name: W. H. Auden – Lullaby
Line1: Lay your sleeping head, my love,
Line2: Human on my faithless arm;
Line3: Time and fevers burn away
Line4: Individual beauty from
Line5: Thoughtful children, and the grave
Line6: Proves the child ephemeral:
Line7: But in my arms till break of day
Line8: Let the living creature lie,
Line9: Mortal, guilty, but to me
Line10: The entirely beautiful.
Line11: Soul and body have no bounds:
Line12: To lovers as they lie upon
Line13: Her tolerant enchanted slope
Line14: In their ordinary swoon,
Line15: Grave the vision Venus sends
Line16: Of supernatural sympathy,
Line17: Universal love and hope;
Line18: While an abstract insight wakes
Line19: Among the glaciers and the rocks
Line20: The hermit's carnal ecstasy.
Line21: Certainty, fidelity
Line22: On the stroke of midnight pass
Line23: Like vibrations of a bell,
Line24: And fashionable madmen raise
Line25: Their pedantic boring cry:
Line27: All the dreaded cards foretell,
Line28: Shall be paid, but from this night
Line29: Not a whisper, not a thought,
Line30: Not a kiss nor look be lost.
Line31: Beauty, midnight, vision dies:
Line32: Let the winds of dawn that blow
Line33: Softly round your dreaming head
Line34: Such a day of welcome show
Line35: Eye and knocking heart may bless,
Line36: Find the mortal world enough;
Line37: Noons of dryness find you fed
Line38: By the involuntary powers,
Line39: Nights of insult let you pass
Line40: Watched by every human love.

Name: W. H. Auden – As I Walked Out One Evening
Line1: As I walked out one evening,
Line2: Walking down Bristol Street,
Line3: The crowds upon the pavement
Line4: Were fields of harvest wheat.
Line5: And down by the brimming river
Line6: I heard a lover sing
Line7: Under an arch of the railway:
Line8: ‘Love has no ending.
Line9: ‘I’ll love you, dear, I’ll love you
Line10: Till China and Africa meet,
Line11: And the river jumps over the mountain
Line12: And the salmon sing in the street,
Line13: ‘I’ll love you till the ocean
Line14: Is folded and hung up to dry
Line15: And the seven stars go squawking
Line16: Like geese about the sky.
Line17: ‘The years shall run like rabbits,
Line18: For in my arms I hold
Line19: The Flower of the Ages,
Line20: And the first love of the world.’
Line21: But all the clocks in the city
Line22: Began to whirr and chime:
Line23: ‘O let not Time deceive you,
Line24: You cannot conquer Time.
Line25: ‘In the burrows of the Nightmare
Line27: Time watches from the shadow
Line28: And coughs when you would kiss.
Line29: ‘In headaches and in worry
Line30: Vaguely life leaks away,
Line31: And Time will have his fancy
Line32: To-morrow or to-day.
Line33: ‘Into many a green valley
Line34: Drifts the appalling snow;
Line35: Time breaks the threaded dances
Line36: And the diver’s brilliant bow.
Line37: ‘O plunge your hands in water,
Line38: Plunge them in up to the wrist;
Line39: Stare, stare in the basin
Line40: And wonder what you’ve missed.
Line41: ‘The glacier knocks in the cupboard,
Line42: The desert sighs in the bed,
Line43: And the crack in the tea-cup opens
Line44: A lane to the land of the dead.
Line46: And the Giant is enchanting to Jack,
Line47: And the Lily-white Boy is a Roarer,
Line48: And Jill goes down on her back.
Line49: ‘O look, look in the mirror,
Line50: O look in your distress:

Name: W. H. Auden – Epitaph on a Tyrant
Line1: Perfection, of a kind, was what he was after,
Line2: And the poetry he invented was easy to understand;
Line3: He knew human folly like the back of his hand,
Line4: And was greatly interested in armies and fleets;
Line5: When he laughed, respectable senators burst with laughter,
Line6: And when he cried the little children died in the streets.

Name: W. H. Auden – In Memory of W. B. Yeats
Line1: I
Line2: He disappeared in the dead of winter:
Line3: The brooks were frozen, the airports almost deserted,
Line4: And snow disfigured the public statues;
Line5: The mercury sank in the mouth of the dying day.
Line6: What instruments we have agree
Line7: The day of his death was a dark cold day.
Line8: Far from his illness
Line9: The wolves ran on through the evergreen forests,
Line10: The peasant river was untempted by the fashionable quays;
Line11: By mourning tongues
Line12: The death of the poet was kept from his poems.
Line13: But for him it was his last afternoon as himself,
Line14: An afternoon of nurses and rumours;
Line15: The provinces of his body revolted,
Line16: The squares of his mind were empty,
Line17: Silence invaded the suburbs,
Line18: The current of his feeling failed; he became his admirers.
Line19: Now he is scattered among a hundred cities
Line20: And wholly given over to unfamiliar affections,
Line21: To find his happiness in another kind of wood
Line22: And be punished under a foreign code of conscience.
Line23: The words of a dead man
Line24: Are modified in the guts of the living.
Line25: But in the importance and noise of to-morrow
Line26: When the brokers are roaring like beasts on the floor of the bourse,
Line27: And the poor have the sufferings to which they are fairly accustomed
Line28: And each in the cell of himself is almost convinced of his freedom
Line29: A few thousand will think of this day
Line30: As one thinks of a day when one did something slightly unusual.
Line31: What instruments we have agree
Line32: The day of his death was a dark cold day.
Line33: II
Line34: You were silly like us; your gift survived it all:
Line35: The parish of rich women, physical decay,
Line36: Yourself. Mad Ireland hurt you into poetry.
Line37: Now Ireland has her madness and her weather still,
Line38: For poetry makes nothing happen: it survives
Line39: In the valley of its making where executives
Line40: Would never want to tamper, flows on south
Line41: From ranches of isolation and the busy griefs,
Line42: Raw towns that we believe and die in; it survives,
Line43: A way of happening, a mouth.
Line44: III
Line46: William Yeats is laid to rest.
Line47: Let the Irish vessel lie
Line48: Emptied of its poetry.
Line49: In the nightmare of the dark
Line50: All the dogs of Europe bark,

Name: W. H. Auden – September 1, 1939
Line1: I sit in one of the dives
Line2: On Fifty-second Street
Line3: Uncertain and afraid
Line4: As the clever hopes expire
Line5: Of a low dishonest decade:
Line6: Waves of anger and fear
Line7: Circulate over the bright
Line8: And darkened lands of the earth,
Line9: Obsessing our private lives;
Line10: The unmentionable odour of death
Line11: Offends the September night.
Line12: Accurate scholarship can
Line13: Unearth the whole offence
Line14: From Luther until now
Line15: That has driven a culture mad,
Line16: Find what occurred at Linz,
Line17: What huge imago made
Line18: A psychopathic god:
Line19: I and the public know
Line20: What all schoolchildren learn,
Line21: Those to whom evil is done
Line22: Do evil in return.
Line23: Exiled Thucydides knew
Line24: All that a speech can say
Line25: About Democracy,
Line27: The elderly rubbish they talk
Line28: To an apathetic grave;
Line29: Analysed all in his book,
Line30: The enlightenment driven away,
Line31: The habit-forming pain,
Line32: Mismanagement and grief:
Line33: We must suffer them all again.
Line34: Into this neutral air
Line35: Where blind skyscrapers use
Line36: Their full height to proclaim
Line37: The strength of Collective Man,
Line38: Each language pours its vain
Line39: Competitive excuse:
Line40: But who can live for long
Line41: In an euphoric dream;
Line42: Out of the mirror they stare,
Line43: Imperialism's face
Line44: And the international wrong.
Line46: Cling to their average day:
Line47: The lights must never go out,
Line48: The music must always play,
Line49: All the conventions conspire
Line50: To make this fort assume

Name: W. H. Auden – In Memory of Sigmund Freud
Line1: When there are so many we shall have to mourn,
Line2: when grief has been made so public, and exposed
Line3: to the critique of a whole epoch
Line4: the frailty of our conscience and anguish,
Line5: of whom shall we speak? For every day they die
Line6: among us, those who were doing us some good,
Line7: who knew it was never enough but
Line8: hoped to improve a little by living.
Line9: Such was this doctor: still at eighty he wished
Line10: to think of our life from whose unruliness
Line11: so many plausible young futures
Line12: with threats or flattery ask obedience,
Line13: but his wish was denied him: he closed his eyes
Line14: upon that last picture, common to us all,
Line15: of problems like relatives gathered
Line16: puzzled and jealous about our dying.
Line17: For about him till the very end were still
Line18: those he had studied, the fauna of the night,
Line19: and shades that still waited to enter
Line20: the bright circle of his recognition
Line21: turned elsewhere with their disappointment as he
Line22: was taken away from his life interest
Line23: to go back to the earth in London,
Line24: an important Jew who died in exile.
Line25: Only Hate was happy, hoping to augment
Line26: his practice now, and his dingy clientele
Line27: who think they can be cured by killing
Line28: and covering the garden with ashes.
Line29: They are still alive, but in a world he changed
Line30: simply by looking back with no false regrets;
Line31: all he did was to remember
Line32: like the old and be honest like children.
Line33: He wasn't clever at all: he merely told
Line34: the unhappy Present to recite the Past
Line35: like a poetry lesson till sooner
Line36: or later it faltered at the line where
Line37: long ago the accusations had begun,
Line38: and suddenly knew by whom it had been judged,
Line39: how rich life had been and how silly,
Line40: and was life-forgiven and more humble,
Line41: able to approach the Future as a friend
Line42: without a wardrobe of excuses, without

Name: Alfred Noyes – The Highwayman
Line1: PART ONE
Line2: The wind was a torrent of darkness among the gusty trees.
Line3: The moon was a ghostly galleon tossed upon cloudy seas.
Line4: The road was a ribbon of moonlight over the purple moor,
Line5: And the highwayman came riding—
Line6: Riding—riding—
Line7: The highwayman came riding, up to the old inn-door.
Line8: He’d a French cocked-hat on his forehead, a bunch of lace at his chin,
Line9: A coat of the claret velvet, and breeches of brown doe-skin.
Line10: They fitted with never a wrinkle. His boots were up to the thigh.
Line11: And he rode with a jewelled twinkle,
Line12: His pistol butts a-twinkle,
Line13: His rapier hilt a-twinkle, under the jewelled sky.
Line14: Over the cobbles he clattered and clashed in the dark inn-yard.
Line15: He tapped with his whip on the shutters, but all was locked and barred.
Line16: He whistled a tune to the window, and who should be waiting there
Line17: But the landlord’s black-eyed daughter,
Line18: Bess, the landlord’s daughter,
Line19: Plaiting a dark red love-knot into her long black hair.
Line20: And dark in the dark old inn-yard a stable-wicket creaked
Line21: Where Tim the ostler listened. His face was white and peaked.
Line22: His eyes were hollows of madness, his hair like mouldy hay,
Line23: But he loved the landlord’s daughter,
Line24: The landlord’s red-lipped daughter.
Line25: Dumb as a dog he listened, and he heard the robber say—
Line26: “One kiss, my bonny sweetheart, I’m after a prize to-night,
Line27: But I shall be back with the yellow gold before the morning light;
Line28: Yet, if they press me sharply, and harry me through the day,
Line29: Then look for me by moonlight,
Line30: Watch for me by moonlight,
Line31: I’ll come to thee by moonlight, though hell should bar the way.”
Line32: He rose upright in the stirrups. He scarce could reach her hand,
Line33: But she loosened her hair in the casement. His face burnt like a brand
Line34: As the black cascade of perfume came tumbling over his breast;
Line35: And he kissed its waves in the moonlight,
Line36: (O, sweet black waves in the moonlight!)
Line37: Then he tugged at his rein in the moonlight, and galloped away to the west.
Line38: PART TWO
Line39: He did not come in the dawning. He did not come at noon;
Line40: And out of the tawny sunset, before the rise of the moon,
Line41: When the road was a gypsy’s ribbon, looping the purple moor,
Line42: A red-coat troop came marching—
Line43: Marching—marching—
Line44: King George’s men came marching, up to the old inn-door.
Line45: They said no word to the landlord. They drank his ale instead.
Line46: But they gagged his daughter, and bound her, to the foot of her narrow bed.
Line47: Two of them knelt at her casement, with muskets at their side!
Line48: There was death at every window;
Line49: And hell at one dark window;
Line50: For Bess could see, through her casement, the road that he would ride.

Name: W. H. Auden – The More Loving One
